    When you want to magically change your appearance, name, gender, title, ancestry, classes, or talents, find an echo.

    Once you find an echo, the changes take place. This is always a willing exchange, as the process can only take place with a willing echo. One thing that can't change are your life experiences, which remain the same.

    This activity can be used to fully retrain your character, or to change your character's appearance to better match your image of them. It is not intended for shenanigans like getting away with crimes by changing your appearance, and characters trying to do so will discover that they can't find any suitable echoes.

    Remember, you can make some changes to your character when they level up. Specifically, you can reassign any number of ranks in one talent to another and reassign any number of ranks in a class to another class. This activity is for bigger, more encompassing changes.

    GAIN A CONTACT

    Contacts are relationships that can be leveraged for benefits. They can be people with any sort of relationship to a beacon, from close friends to rivals or even mortal enemies. Whatever the relationship, a contact can get you something you want.

    When you want to find a person that can help you, name either a specific individual or a general category of person (dockworker, business executive, town guard, etc.), then roll:

    • 9 or less (Miss): You gain the contact, but you will need to earn their trust or deepen your relationship with them before they will do anything for you.
    • 10-19 (Hit): You gain this contact and they will perform a minor or moderate favor for you, but they will likely ask for something in return after doing so.
    • 20+ (Crit): You gain this contact and they will perform a minor or moderate favor for you at no cost, or a major favor for which they will expect a favor in return.

    Once the roll is made, the GM should set up a brief narrative scene to roleplay how they became your contact. The GM can disallow certain characters from becoming contacts, and should indicate this before a roll is made to gain them as a contact. GMs, don't make players use the downtime activity if it is impossible succeed.

    GET SOMETHING

    Beacons can easily acquire common or mundane items like food, armor, and weaponry. Some things are harder to obtain - just out of a beacon's reach, but not impossible to grasp.

    When you want to acquire something important, name what it is and roll:

    • 9 or less (Miss): You can get it, but at great cost. You either have to give up something you don't want to lose, or do something you don't want to do for someone.
    • 10-19 (Hit): You can get it, but you will owe something to someone.
    • 20+ (Crit): You can get it, no strings attached. Next time you try to GET SOMETHING the same way, treat this result as a 10-19 instead.

    Before you commit to performing this activity, the GM will let you know if the thing you want can't be obtained this way.

    GO SHOPPING

    This downtime activity allows beacons to buy valuable items and SUPPLIES , or sell valuable items and loot for GOLD . When using it, keep in mind that beacons are always able to cover their basic needs, like food, housing, and their starting and unlocked equipment.

    There are two versions of this downtime activity: Buying and Selling .

    BUYING

    When you want to buy supplies or other valuable items, ask the GM for the available shops and their stock.

    Buying SUPPLIES or valuable items costs GOLD . Y ou can buy as many items as you want from the shops available. The GM determines which shops are available, what they have in stock, and their prices, either manually picking options or randomly generating them (see p. 346). The goods in stock are the same for all beacons for the rest of the downtime period. The general store is always available.

    A full list of shops and their SUPPLIES can be found in Appendix A: Shops and Supplies (p. 346).

    SELLING

    When you want to sell loot or other valuable items, name the items or loot and roll for each item:

    • 9 or less (Miss): Y ou can only sell it for -1 GOLD below its base price at this time. You can try again with a future downtime activity.
    • 10-19 (Hit): You can sell it for its base price.
    • 20+ (Crit): Y ou can sell it for +1 GOLD above its base price.

    The GM will set a base price of 1-3 GOLD . For loot, the rarity of the loot determines its price ( Uncommon: 2 GOLD ; Rare: 4 GOLD ; Legendary: 6 GOLD ).

    WISHLISTING

    When one beacon performs the SHOP downtime activity, other beacons can also do so for free. Performing this activity for free is called WISHLISTING . When WISHLISTING , a beacon can only buy or sell one item.

    SHOPS SUPPLIES
    GENERAL STORE Adventuring supplies (p. 346)
    ALCHEMY SHOP Potions and elixirs (p. 347)
    BLACKSMITH Gear and equipment (p. 349)
    ENGINEER Magitech andcutting-edge tech (p. 352)
    TAVERN Food and drink (p. 354)
    LEATHERWORKER/ CLOTHIER Gear and clothing (p. 350)
    MAGIC SHOP/DOJO Temporary techniques (p. 355)

    HIT THE BOOKS

    Libraries, schools, and other repositories of information are valuable tools for beacons.

    When you want to research or learn about something, name what you want to learn and roll:

    • 9 or less (Miss): You can ask the GM up to two questions about your topic before they answer. One of their answers can be untrue.
    • 10-19 (Hit): You can ask the GM up to three questions about your topic before they answer. One of their answers can be untrue.
    • 20+ (Crit): Y ou can ask the GM up to two questions about your topic, and both answers will be true. You don't need to ask both questions at the same time.

    GettinG Started

    4: narrative Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game aPPendiceS

    IMPRINT A CRYSTAL

    Beacons can imprint memories of themselves onto special gems called job crystals. By focusing on a memory and weaving their aetheric field into the crystal, an imprint of that memory is made. Beacons holding a job crystal containing one of their imprints can access that memory by reweaving their aetheric field into it, overwriting certain features of themselves with the ones from the imprinted memory.

    When you want to imprint a specific loadout onto a job crystal, pick any number of the following elements to imprint:

    • An ancestry trait
    • A job
    • Weapons
    • Support items
    • Techniques
    • Clothing and general appearance

    In narrative play , when you have a few moments to focus, you can replace your clothing, equipment, and gear with those imprinted on the crystal.

    During a Short Rest or a Long Rest , you can replace your loadout with the imprinted loadout without spending a RECOVERY . The following caveats apply:

    • Your current HP , MP , Stress, and RECOVERIES don't change unless the new maximums are lower than your current values, at which point they are reduced to equal the new maximum.
    • If any equipment or techniques have been destroyed, their loss carries over to the new loadout:
    • For every destroyed piece of equipment, a piece of the new loadout's equipment must be destroyed. The destroyed equipment must be of the same size, if possible. If there is nothing of matching size, something of the next largest size is destroyed instead. For example, if one of your LIGHT weapons has been destroyed, one of the new loadout's LIGHT weapons must also be destroyed. If the new loadout doesn't have any LIGHT weapons, then you have to destroy a MAIN or HEAVY weapon instead.
    • For every destroyed technique, a number of the new loadout's techniques must be destroyed with a MEMORY cost equal or greater than the MEMORY cost of the destroyed techniques from the old loadout.

    Equipment and techniques with the Consumable or Limited tags and no charges left count as destroyed when using an imprint.

    A beacon can have one imprinted crystal at a time, and crystals can be used multiple times. To be used, the loadout imprinted on a crystal must have at least one difference from your current loadout. If an imprint matches the current loadout, it can't be used.

    MAKE SOMETHING

    Beacons are capable of creating incredible items, whether they be suits that can survive the crushing depths of the ocean or airship engines that can traverse a storm wall.

    When you want to make something special, answer the following questions and roll:

    • What does it do?
    • Why is it special?
    • What is it made of?
    • 9 or less (Miss): Something goes wrong in the design or crafting process. The GM picks two complications (see below).
    • 10-19 (Hit): The object is more complicated than you expected. The GM picks one complication.
    • 20+ (Crit): You make it with no complications.

    COMPLICATIONS

    • It's expensive.
    • It requires a rare or unique ingredient.
    • It's unreliable or temporary.
    • It takes longer to make than you thought. You can automatically finish it by performing this activity again in a subsequent downtime period (no roll required) and meeting all of the other conditions.
    • You need help from _____.

    Objects made using this activity are not usable in combat play. Once you've made an item, you can use this downtime activity to make the same item again without rolling as long as you have the ingredients. Record your answers as the 'recipe' for the item.

    This activity is for making special items. If a beacon wants to make something simple or uncomplicated, like carving a wooden duck, they can make it with a skill check at the GM discretion, instead of using a downtime activity.

    PURSUE A PROFESSION

    Pursuing a profession can be a good way to earn GOLD or obtain SUPPLIES .

    Pursuing a profession has two steps, each of which is a downtime activity: Learn a Profession and Work a Profession .

    LEARN A PROFESSION

    When you want to learn a new profession, pick one of the professions listed below, or create one and pick the type of business that you think would be connected to it from those listed below.

    You gain a new rank 1 background skill named for that profession. This background skill can be improved like a normal background skill.

    You can have a maximum of two professions at a time, after which you can take this downtime activity to replace a known profession with a new one at rank 1. When you learn a profession, you can immediately Work a Profession using that profession.

    PROFESSION BUSINESS
    ALCHEMY Alchemy Shop
    CARPENTRY Engineer or Leatherworker/ Clothier
    COOKING Tavern
    ENCHANTING Magic Shop/Dojo
    ENGINEERING Engineer
    FISHING Tavern
    HERBALISM Alchemy Shop or Tavern
    LAPIDARY General Store or Engineer
    LEATHERWORKING Leatherworker/Clothier
    MINING Blacksmith
    SCRIBING Magic Shop/Dojo
    SKINNING Leatherworker/Clothier
    SMITHING Blacksmith
    TAILORING Leatherworker/Clothier

    WORK A PROFESSION

    When want to use your profession to earn GOLD , roll with your profession's background skill:

    • 9 or less (Miss): You gain 1 GOLD .
    • 10-19 (Hit): You gain 3 GOLD .
    • 20+ (Crit): You gain 5 GOLD .

    You can then immediately gain one supply with a GOLD cost equal to or lower than your ranks in that profession's background skill. It must be available from the type of shop connected to your profession, but you can do this even if that shop wouldn't otherwise be available. As with the SHOP downtime activity, the GM will provide you with the available stock.

    RUN AN ORGANIZATION

    Beacons often have jobs, whether running stores or leading guilds.

    Running an organization has two steps, which are downtime activities: Create an Organization and Manage an Organization .

    CREATE AN ORGANIZATION

    When you want to create an organization or business, answer the following:

    • What is the name of the organization?
    • What does the organization specialize in?

    You create the organization. It counts as a special background skill that starts at rank 0, and can range between -3 and +3 ranks. You can't increase its ranks with normal background skill points.

    When you create an organization, you can immediately Manage an Organization for that organization.

    MANAGE AN ORGANIZATION

    When you want to manage an organization or business, roll with your organization skill:

    • 9 or less (Miss): Reduce the rank of your organization skill by -2.
    • 10-19 (Hit): Increase the rank of your organization skill by +1.
    • 20+ (Crit): Increase the rank of your organization skill by +2.

    The organization can be used like a background skill in situations that match its specialty. Whenever you use it like this, reduce its rank by -1 after using it. If you have negative ranks in this skill, you gain equal to the negative ranks when using it.

    4: narrative Play runninG tHe Game

    When using the Go Shopping downtime activity, you can spend ranks from your organization skill in lieu of GOLD . Each rank spent counts as 1 GOLD , to a maximum of 3 GOLD .

    You can also have your organization act on your behalf at the cost of one rank, calling on it to do things that you as an individual wouldn't be able to do.

    You can spend 2 GOLD to increase the rank of your organization skill by +1.

    TAKE A BREATHER

    Sometimes you just need to relax. Some people spend time reading books or enjoying nature, while others meet with friends or hit the town.

    When you want to partake in an activity you enjoy or find relaxing, name what you are doing to relax and roll:

    • 9 or less (Miss): It had the opposite effect, and you are now more stressed than you started. You and the GM each choose one of the following:
    • You couldn't stop thinking about _____.
    • You made a fool of yourself.
    • You overindulged, and now you're hurting.
    • Something went wrong.
    • You lost track of time and missed or forgot something.
    • You spent more money than you should have.
    • You made an enemy.
    • 10-19 (Hit): Choose one of the following, and one from the above list:
    • You meet an interesting person or make a friend.
    • You gain an interesting or useful piece of information.
    • You develop a reputation of your choice.
    • You deepen your relationship with someone.
    • 20+ (Crit): You get one option from the 10-19 list with no drawbacks.

    TRAINING

    Training allows beacons to improve, gain new skills, or even learn new fighting styles.

    When you want to learn something new or improve an existing ability, pick one of the following to train:

    • A background skill: you either gain a new background skill at rank 1 or improve an existing skill by one rank
    • A class: choose any class and roll:
    • 9 or less (Miss): It is hard to learn anything practical about this class. Unlock a weapon, support item, or technique from the chosen class. It can only be used in the next quest.
    • 10-19 (Hit): You've made progress in the fundamentals of the class. Unlock up to two weapons, support items, or techniques from the chosen class. They can only be used in the next quest.
    • 20+ (Crit): Y ou've begun to master the intricacies of the class. You can choose to equip that class's job for the next quest, and you unlock up to two weapons, support items, or techniques from the class. They can only be used in the next quest.

    SKILL CHALLENGES

    Skill challenges are series of rapid skill checks. They can be used for fast-paced narrative scenes, montages, and other streamlined scenes.

    Skill challenges can be split into two categories: story challenges and adversity challenges .

    STORY CHALLENGES

    A rooftop chase, a journey across a pirate infested sea, and navigating a bureaucratic nightmare are all examples of potential story challenges.

    Story challenges are used when an obstacle or scene is too complex to be resolved with a single skill check. A GM can declare a story challenge is required in any narrative scene.

    Story challenges exist purely within narrative play. The actions they involve and their consequences have no impact on combat, unlike adversity challenges, which directly impact combat scenes.

    Story challenges are structured as follows:

    Goal: The GM lays out the end goal of the challenge. It could be something like 'catch this person before they escape' or 'get to your destination safely' .

    Difficulty: The GM sets the difficulty of the challenge. This determines the number of successful skill checks the players need to achieve their goal.

    • Simple: Successes required = number of PCs.
    • Moderate: Successes required = number of PCs 1.5.
    • Challenging: Successes required = number of PCs 2.

    Resolution: The players take turns describing what their characters are doing in pursuit of the goal and making skill checks to determine how impactful or successful they are. Misses count as failures, and hits and crits count as successes.

    If the players collectively reach three failed skill checks , they fail the challenge. They do not achieve their goal and the GM describe what happens next. For example, the target could escape, the beacons arrive too late, or they don't get the necessary backing they need.

    Once every beacon has taken a turn, if they haven't yet succeeded or failed the challenge, they go again in any order. Repeat until the beacons succeed or fail the challenge.

    Example: The beacons need to capture a spy who is fleeing across the city rooftops. The GM declares a standard skill challenge. They set the goal as 'capture the spy before they reach their submarine' with a simple difficulty. There are four beacons, so they need to achieve four successes before three failures.

    Dhalia goes first and uses her 'Disciple of the Sun' background skill to create a magical spotlight on the spy so they're easier to track. She rolls a 14, which is a hit and the first of the four successes they need (1/4 successes).

    Dmitri goes second. He wants to immediately tackle and pin the spy, but since they need three more successes to win the skill challenge, he can't do that yet since it would end the skill challenge. Instead, he throws things at the spy to slow them down with his 'Perfected Body' background skill. He rolls a 20 - another success (2/4).

    Mallory is next. She decides to steal someone's horse to get ahead of the spy and cut off their escape route. She doesn't have a background skill to use. She rolls an 8, which is their first failure. Two more and they'll fail the challenge!

    Barbazar sees Mallory's struggles and wants to help. Since Mallory is a small halfling and Barbazar is incredibly strong, she offers to pick Mallory up and throw her ahead. Mallory loves this idea, so Barbazar rolls with her 'Bend Bars and Lift Gates' background skill and gets an 18, their third success (3/4).

    Everyone has taken a turn, so they go again. Because they're one success away from winning the challenge, everyone thinks it would be funny if Mallory were the one to catch the spy after being thrown like a missile. Mallory makes a roll with her 'Murderous Ball of Death' background skill and gets a 10, which is enough for their fourth and final success (4/4)!

    The GM describes how Mallory slams into the spy, sending them both tumbling into an alley below where the rest of the beacons are able to restrain them.

    4: narrative Play

    ADVERSITY CHALLENGES

    Adversity challenges are special skill challenges used during quests. They can be used as the basis for whole scenes or montages of scenes within a quest, with direct implications for combat scenes. These challenges represent the obstacles the beacons encounter between combat scenes, like moving through dangerous rooms in a dungeon or sneaking past some patrolling guards to ambush a target.

    In an adversity challenge, the beacons will get to their goal. Unlike story challenges, where the outcome is uncertain, adversity challenges are about how well the beacons handle their challenges.

    Adversity challenges are structured as follows:

    Goal: The GM lays out the end goal for the beacons. It could be something like 'find the end of the dungeon' or 'get to the leader of the enemy army' .

    Adversities: The GM describes the adversities the beacons will face. These can be people, things, or events that the beacons will need to deal with, like the traps in the dungeon or the soldiers in the enemy army. Adversities provide the PCs with guidance on how to describe their actions, letting them know what problems they should describe their character solving.

    Adversity challenges can have any number of adversities, but they should ideally have at least as many the number of consequences (see below). The Adversities section (p. 38) has a list of sample adversities.

    Consequences: Adversities can have consequences attached to them. Consequences are things that grant negative effects to the next combat scene if they aren't overcome. Beacons can overcome consequences as part of the resolution of the adversity challenge. The number of consequences is determined by the difficulty of the challenge:

    • Simple: half the number of PCs.

    • Moderate: the number of PCs.

    • Challenging: the number of PCs + 2.

    The players should be aware of the effect of each consequence and which adversity it is associated with. Beacons aren't required to overcome all consequences, and in fact it is impossible to do so at the challenging difficulty level. Deciding which adversities to overcome and which to accept is one of the tactical decisions to be made in an adversity challenge.

    A list of consequences can be found in the Consequences section (p. 38).

    Resolution: In an adversity challenge, each PC makes a single skill check. To do so, they first pick an approach . The six approaches represent different ways they can approach the skill check, and offer players the option to either overcome consequences or gain benefits in the next combat scene.

    After selecting an approach, you describe how your beacon is contributing to the challenge. If you want to overcome a consequence, you must specifically describe how your beacon is attempting to do so. Once you've described what you want to do, you make a skill check:

    • 9 or less (Miss): You fail to make any progress. You don't get to choose any benefits from your approach.
    • 10-19 (Hit): Y ou can select one option from the hit list for your chosen approach.
    • 20+ (Crit): You can select one option from either the hit list or the crit list for your chosen approach.

    Once all the players have selected their approach, described their actions, and rolled their skill check, the GM describes the final resolution of the challenge and what happens next.

    Approaches

    The six approaches are: Endure , Infiltrate , Prepare , Scout , Sway , and Whittle . When you choose an approach, your skill check must be something that could reasonably fall under the selected approach. For example, if you want to hold up a crumbling wall so your allies can escape, it would make sense to use ENDURE , but SWAY wouldn't make sense.

    When choosing an option from an approach's hit list or crit list, you can do so either immediately or at the start of the next combat scene, after the GM describes the type of combat and deployment but before the first round of combat begins. Any unchosen options are lost once the combat scene begins, and the benefits chosen only apply to the next combat scene.

    Options with the [ TEAM ] tag can only be selected once per skill challenge.

    ENDURE

    Weather the storm and stand strong, enduring whatever trials come your way.

    HIT

    Overcome: You overcome a consequence.

    Armorer: You repair one destroyed technique or piece of equipment.

    Adrenaline: You gain resistance to Physical, Force, Astral, and Lunar until the end of the first round of combat.

    Bolstered: You start combat with 4 TEMP HP.

    Defensive: An ally of your choice starts combat with 3 FOCUS.

    Used to pain: Choose either Wounds or Overstress. If you would take one of the options you selected, you can roll twice for your wound or overstress roll and take the better result.

    CRIT

    Surpass: You overcome a consequence and may choose one option from the hit list.

    Focused: Your Stress can't go above your BREAKING point until the end of the first round of combat.

    Unfazed: You gain 3 Unfazed. Whenever you would gain a condition not caused by yourself, you can spend 1 to not gain the condition.

    Sturdy: Your HP can't be reduced below your BLOODIED value until the end of the first round of combat.

    Hardened: You gain +2 ARMOR .

    INFILTRATE

    Surprise your opponents or gain an advantageous position by moving undetected.

    HIT

    Overcome: You overcome a consequence.

    Ambush: 1/round when you make an attack roll while HIDDEN , you can roll the d20 twice and take the best result.

    Trapped Environment: You can place three Traps in free spaces on the map. Characters that trigger one of the Traps take [6 Physical, Astral, Lunar, or Force] (chosen by you at the time of placement) and must pass an Agility save or be Slowed until the end of their next turn.

    In the Shadows: You start combat HIDDEN .

    Surprise: You can take your first turn during PHASE BOLSTER and use any action during that phase.

    Forward Position: When you deploy for combat, you can deploy up to 8 spaces further away than normal.

    CRIT

    Surpass: You overcome a consequence and may choose one option from the hit list.

    Cloak of Shadows: You start combat HIDDEN and INVISIBLE. You remain INVISIBLE until you make an attack, deal damage, or force a save.

    Marked For death: Choose a non-Boss NPC. 1/round when you consume a MARK on them and successfully hit with an attack that deals Physical, Force, Astral, or Lunar, the damage is increased by the result of the highest die rolled.

    Pass without Trace: All PCs start combat HIDDEN and can't lose HIDDEN until they take a turn or an enemy ends a turn adjacent to them.

    Spread Out (team): At the start of the first round of combat, all PCs can immediately move up to their SPEED.

    GettinG Started

    4: narrative Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game aPPendiceS

    GettinG Started

    4: narrative Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game aPPendiceS

    PREPARE

    Research your enemies, create a plan, and trust in your preparations to bring you to victory.

    HIT

    Overcome: You overcome a consequence.

    Defensive: ally of your choice starts combat with 3 FOCUS.

    Encyclopedia: You and the other PCs know if any deployed enemies have abilities that grant resistance or immunity or that make them VULNERABLE, and what those abilities do. This includes abilities with conditional triggers (e.g., resistance that only applies in certain situations).

    IdentiFy: You can learn the ability scores, attributes, and abilities of one non-boss NPC of your choice.

    Precast: The first time you use an ability that costs MP, it costs -2 MP less than usual.

    Prepared: You can switch one intact weapon, support item, ancestry trait, or technique you have equipped with a different one that you would be able to equip.

    CRIT

    Surpass: You overcome a consequence and may choose one option from the hit list.

    Ready: At the start of each round of combat, you can READY an action. Each action can be readied once.

    Plan [team]: At the start of a single round, you can enact your plan. All non-boss NPCs count as having base initiative 8 until the end of the round.

    Restock: You regain all charges of one Consumable ability.

    Well Rested: Your SURGE level immediately decreases by one.

    SCOUT

    Perform recon on who you're fighting and the environment you're fighting in to gain an advantage.

    HIT

    Overcome: You overcome a consequence.

    Know positions: You can move one non-Boss NPC to another free space within their deployment zone. If there isn't a set NPC deployment zone, you can move them to a free space within RANGE 8.

    Prioritize: Three enemies of your choice become MARKED.

    Searching eye: Choose an enemy. You and the other PCs always know their current HP and Stress.

    Know enemies: Your enemies can't start combat HIDDEN or INVISIBLE and can't become HIDDEN or INVISIBLE during their first turn.

    IdentiFy: You can learn the ability scores, attributes, and abilities of one non-Boss NPC of your choice.

    CRIT

    Surpass: You overcome a consequence and may choose one option from the hit list.

    Change gear: Once during combat, you can switch one weapon, support item, ancestry trait, or technique you have equipped, even a destroyed one, with a different one that you would be able to equip.

    Study: You and your allies know the current HP, Stress, and MP of all enemies.

    Weak point: Choose a non-Boss enemy. They become VULNERABLE to Physical, Astral, Lunar, or Force (your choice) for the rest of the scene.

    Tactical position: When you deploy, choose two options from the list below. If placing cover or terrain, you can place it in free spaces on the map:

    • Place 4 pieces of SIZE 1 hard cover
    • Place 2 pieces of SIZE 2 hard cover
    • Place 6 spaces of difficult terrain
    • Place 4 spaces of dangerous terrain ( AGILITY , 5 Physical )
    • Remove 4 pieces of SIZE 1 cover
    • Remove 2 pieces of SIZE 2 cover

    SWAY

    Bluff, lie, or charm your way to your destination.

    HIT

    Overcome: You overcome a consequence.

    Betrayal: One non-Boss NPC of your choice is DISARMED or SILENCED until the end of their first turn.

    ConFlicted Feelings: Non-Boss NPCs take 1 STRESS every time they damage you.

    Confused: A non-Boss NPC of your choice treats their first Initiative as 8 during the first round of combat.

    Friend: A non-Boss NPC of your choice receives +1 on attacks against you until you deal damage or Stress to them.

    Share: You regain a RECOVERY.

    CRIT

    Surpass: You overcome a consequence and may choose one option from the hit list.

    Buddy: You can change your starting position to be adjacent to an enemy of your choice.

    Turncoat: The GM will choose a non-Boss NPC to change allegiance to your side during the next combat. They deploy with the PCs, in the PC deployment zone.

    Unprepared enemies: Y ou decide where all NPCs deploy. The GM will tell you the boundaries within which you can deploy.

    False reports (team):You gain control over enemy reinforcements. The GM shares the list of reinforcements with you, and you can decide the order in which they are deployed and where. You can delay creating reinforcements for 1 round, but otherwise can't prevent reinforcements from appearing.

    WHITTLE

    Take out foes and cut your way through to your destination.

    HIT

    Overcome: You overcome a consequence.

    Adrenaline: You gain resistance to Physical, Force, Astral, and Lunar until the end of the first round.

    Battered: One enemy of your choice deals half damage on their first ability that deals damage.

    Bruised: One non-Boss NPC of your choice is always considered BLOODIED regardless of how much HP they actually have.

    Limp: One enemy of your choice is Slowed until the end of their first turn.

    Stressed out: One non-Boss, non-Minion NPC of the GM's choice starts combat at their BREAKING point.

    CRIT

    Surpass: You overcome a consequence and may choose one option from the hit list.

    Channel ruSH: You can instantly release your first CHANNEL ability when used instead of waiting until PHASE RELEASE.

    Wounded: One non-Boss NPC of your choice starts the combat with their HP at their BLOODIED value.

    Fear: Enemies that have line of sight to you receive +1 on all attacks against you.

    Crit Fisher: You automatically score a crit on your first attack roll of 15+. You then score a crit hit on your next attack roll of 16+. This target increases by +1 every time you score a crit on an attack until it reaches 20.

    GettinG Started

    4: narrative Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game aPPendiceS

    Adversities

    Below is a list of example adversities that might appear in an adversity challenge.

    For example, crossing the Duskwood Forest might involve ' dangerous fauna ' and a ' monster infestation ' as adversities.

    ADVERSITIES ADVERSITIES
    1 Adoring fans
    2 Ambush
    3 Armed guards
    4 Blockade
    5 Dangerous fauna
    6 Destroyed path
    7 Extreme weather
    8 Lack of sleep
    9 Locked door
    10 Monster infestation
    11 People that need help
    12 Poisoned
    13 Political machinations
    14 Rival beacons
    15 Shiny distractions
    16 Structural instability
    17 Time loop
    18 Traps
    19 Unfamiliar terrain
    20 Unfriendly locals

    Consequences

    Below are the negative effects that you can apply as a result of the PCs failing to overcome adversities. The players should always be aware of the effects of each adversity they face.

    For example, a dungeon might have 'traps' as an adversity with ' bumps and bruises ' as its consequence, or a bar crawl might have 'poisoned' as an adversity with ' unfocused ' as its consequence.

    As a reminder, consequences only apply to the next combat scene.

    CONSEQUENCES
    1 Broken Each PC has one of their weapons or support items of their choice destroyed.
    2 Bumps and Bruises Each PC loses a RECOVERY.
    3 Captured The GM gets to deploy one of the PCs in any free space that isn't dangerous terrain . That PC is IMMOBILIZED by a set of chains, which are locked (p. 56). Once the chains are unlocked, they are no longer IMMOBILIZED .
    4 Delayed NPCs act before PCs in each phase.
    5 Discovered All PCs start the combat MARKED.
    6 Drained The SURGE level of all PCs increases by one.
    7 Exhausted All PCs are WEAKENED until cleared.
    8 Frustrated All PCs start the combat with their Stress at their BREAKING point.
    9 Hurt PCs can't have more HP than their BLOODIED value.
    10 Mana-Tapped All PCs start the combatwith 0MP.
    11 Surprised All PCs take their first turns during PHASE DELAY, and can'tperform reactions or free actions before that.
    12 Unfocused Each PC has one of their techniques of their choice destroyed.

    Example: The beacons need to destroy a corrupted crystal deposit at the bottom of a mine. The crystal is spawning monsters and weakening the ground, so the GM declares an adversity challenge. They set the goal as 'get to the bottom of the mine' and create three adversities: 'monster infestation' , 'destroyed path' , and 'unfamiliar terrain' . They decide this will be a simple challenge for four PCs, so they create two consequences: monster infestation will have the 'hurt' consequence and the destroyed path will have the 'delayed' consequence.

    The GM describes the scene, explaining how the mine is old and full of dead ends (unfamiliar terrain) and damaged minecart rails (destroyed path), which are the quickest method of navigation. Monsters fill every corner of the mine, spawned from the crystal buried deep within (monster infestation).

    Dhalia goes first. Because the mine is dark, she wants to illuminate it. The Scout approach is the best fit for her plan, so she makes a skill check with her 'Disciple of the Sun' background skill. She gets a 12, which is a hit. She doesn't have a good way to overcome any of the consequences so she holds onto her choice until the next combat scene.

    Barbazar goes next. She wants to use a minecart to get to the bottom of the mine quickly. Because the rails are damaged, her plan is to use her incredible strength to lift and jump the minecarts across the damaged sections. She picks the Endure approach and makes a skill check with her 'Bend Bars and Lift Gates' background skill. She rolls a 14, also a hit. One of her weapons was destroyed in an earlier combat, so she picks the 'Armorer' option to immediately repair it.

    Mallory wants to get rid of the monsters by hacking and slashing at them while riding past them in the minecart. She picks the Whittle approach and makes a skill check with her 'Murderous Ball of Death' background skill. She rolls a 23, which is a crit! She chooses the 'Surpass' option, overcoming the monster infestation consequence and holding her other choice until later.

    The GM decides that the actions of the beacons have gained the attention of a large monster in the mine. They describe a giant monster that starts chasing the PCs down the tunnels, adding a new adversity (but no new consequences).

    Dmitri wants to hold the giant monster off until they can reach the bottom of the mine. He uses the Endure approach and his 'Perfected Body' background skill to jump in the monster's mouth and keep it from biting anyone. He rolls a 17 and immediately chooses the 'Defensive' option.

    Now that every PC has acted, the GM describes how the PCs soar down to the bottom cave, the giant monster stuck in the entrance, too large to enter. The guardian of the crystal materializes and the beacons enter a combat scene. Everyone that didn't already choose a hit or crit effect from their approach can do so now. Because no one overcame the 'destroyed path' consequence, all beacons will suffer the effects of the 'hurt' consequence in this combat.

    4: narrative Play

    GettinG Started

    4: narrative Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game aPPendiceS

    40

    This chapter contains the rules governing combat scenes. Combat scenes are tactical, rules-heavy parts of the game and the main focus of BEACON . This chapter explains how combat scenes work, and the rules and terminology used in combat play.

    By default, there are two sides in every combat scene: the PCs and the NPCs. The rules in this chapter apply to PCs and NPCs, but NPCs have slight differences that are explained in Chapter 11: Non-Playable Characters (p. 259).

    SUMMARY

    Combat in BEACON is composed of a few different units of time: scenes, rounds, phases, and turns.

    Scenes: A scene is an entire combat, from beginning to end. Once the fighting is over, the scene ends.

    Rounds: Each combat scene is made up of a number of rounds , each of which is split up into eight distinct phases . At the end of the eighth phase, the round ends and another round begins.

    Turns: Each character takes one turn per round, taken during one of that round's phases. The action they want to take on their turn determines which phase they act in. On their turn, a character can perform their standard movement , one standard action , one minor action , and any number of free actions (within reason). Most NPCs only take one turn per round, but some NPCs might take multiple turns.

    The players and the GM's NPCs take turns on an alternating basis, with priority going to whichever side (PC or NPC) hasn't acted most recently.

    The PCs generally take the first turn in the first round of a combat scene. When multiple PCs want to take a turn at the same time, the PCs decide their order, and if an agreement can't be made, the GM will decide.

    Example: In the first round of combat, two PCs and one NPC want to act during PHASE SKIRMISH . No characters have taken a turn yet, so one of the PCs gets to take the first turn. Once they've taken their turn, the NPC can take their turn, followed by the final PC.

    Later that round, another PC wants to take their turn during PHASE FULL ATTACK . Normally an NPC could take their turn, but since there are no NPCs that can act during this phase, the PC takes their turn.

    Phases: Phases are the various stages of the round during which characters can act. The phase in which a character takes a turn is usually decided by the action they want to perform, as each action can only be performed in a specific phase. For example, characters can only DEFEND during PHASE BOLSTER and can only GRAPPLE in PHASE BRAWL .

    At the beginning of each phase, the side whose turn it is to act can nominate a character to take a turn (as long as they haven't already taken one this round). Once they've taken their turn, the other side may nominate a character, and so on.

    Once all characters that want to take a turn during a given phase have done so, the next phase begins.

    THE BATTLEFIELD

    Combat scenes in BEACON are played out on a battle map that uses either square or hex-shaped spaces (either is fine). The battlefield is two-dimensional - it is a flat plane, with no vertical spaces; however, there are several mechanisms to represent height advantages, like a character's SIZE and the FLYING status (p. 63).

    INFORMATION TRANSPARENCY

    Information transparency is important in combat scenes. The players should always know:

    • The NPC types and templates for all enemies.
    • The locations of enemies on the map at all times, regardless of line of sight or whether they are HIDDEN or INVISIBLE .
    • The conditions and statuses of all enemies.
    • The battle plan and all relevant goals.
    • The locations of all Traps .
    • The mechanics of any abilities or items that NPCs use.

    Other information is restricted unless a beacon has a specific way to access it. This includes the ability scores and attributes of NPCs and the specific features they have equipped. Certain abilities, like the LORE BOOK support item (p. 218), can provide access to restricted information.

    ENDING THE SCENE

    Combat scenes end when all enemies are defeated or when the combat's objective has been achieved.

    At the end of a combat scene, all effects, conditions, statuses, and combat resources ( TEMP HP , FOCUS ) go away unless explicitly stated.

    5: comBat Play runninG tHe Game

    aPPendiceS

    PHASES

    Each round has the following phases:

    PHASE
    BOLSTER Defend Refresh
    CHANNEL Channel
    SKIRMISH Mark Search Volley
    REPOSITION Rush Hide
    BRAWL Fight Shove Grapple
    RELEASE Release
    FULLATTACK Full Attack
    DELAY Delay
    ANYPHASE Ready

    TURNS

    During their turn, each character can perform one standard movement , one standard action , one minor action , and any number of free actions (within reason) in any order.

    Standard movement: A movement of a number of spaces up to a character's SPEED .

    Standard action: A basic action available during the current phase.

    Minor action: A quick or simple action, often granted by an ability.

    Free action: A special action granted by some abilities. Characters can take any number of free actions during their turn (within reason).

    Certain abilities will indicate either the phase in which they can be performed or an action that must be performed to use them.

    For example, a technique that can only be used in PHASE BOLSTER would say ' PHASE BOLSTER ' . One that specifically requires the DEFEND action - a basic PHASE 1 BOLSTER action - would say '1 DEFEND'.

    If an ability lists an action (e.g., VOLLEY ), you use that action to activate the ability instead of the normal effects of the action. For example, the HEROIC LEAP skill requires the RUSH action to activate. A beacon can use this skill when they take the RUSH action, but can't also move up to their SPEED per the normal RUSH action effects (p. 44). If an ability requires a minor action or free action , it can be performed during any phase as long as it is your turn.

    If an ability lists a phase but not an action (e.g., PHASE SKIRMISH ) activating it requires you to perform it as your standard action during the indicated phase, but it doesn't count as one of that phase's basic actions ( VOLLEY, DEFEND, etc.) for the purposes of triggered effects. For example, the rank 1 Knight talent PHALANX does something when you DEFEND . Using the Aegis spell BARRIER , which has an activation of PHASE BOLSTER , would not trigger that effect, because you are not using the DEFEND action.

    NPCs take their turns in a different way. Each NPC has an INITIATIVE score, and they take their turn in whatever phase matches their INITIATIVE . Unlike PCs, though, their actions aren't limited by the current phase. For example, the Ardent NPC type has INITIATIVE 1 . They always take their turn in PHASE BOLSTER , and they could use their standard action in that phase for any action, not just DEFEND or RECOVER .

    Example: Dhalia wants to attack with her bow, which is a VOLLEY weapon. This requires her to use the VOLLEY action during PHASE SKIRMISH , because that phase allows the use of VOLLEY . If she has any abilities that trigger off of the use of a VOLLEY action, like the PINCER STRIKE loot skill, they also go into effect.

    Later, Dhalia wants to use her MOCK skill from the Skald class. This skill requires a PHASE SKIRMISH action to use, so Dhalia can only use it during PHASE SKIRMISH . Doing so doesn't count as using a MARK , SEARCH , or VOLLEY action.

    SURGING

    Each beacon can SURGE once per round. Doing so allows you to take a second turn at the cost of taking Stress. Each time you SURGE , it costs more Stress.

    All beacons have a SURGE LEVEL , which starts at 0 and determines how much Stress they take from using SURGE (see below). After they SURGE , they increase their SURGE LEVEL by +1, to a maximum of 3. A beacon's SURGE level resets to 0 when they take a Long Rest.

    At the beginning of a SURGE turn, before anything else happens, your beacon takes Stress based on their SURGE level.

    SURGE turns count as normal turns for the purposes of effects that start or end in your next turn. When taking SURGE turns, your beacon can perform their standard movement , standard action , minor action , and free actions as normal. You can't SURGE before you've taken your first turn in a round.

    SURGE LEVEL STRESS COST
    0 2 Stress
    1 1d3+1 Stress
    2 1d6+2 Stress
    3 1d6+4 Stress

    ALTERNATIVE SURGE RULES

    SURGE is a powerful tool that allows PCs to change the game's action economy. Because of this, some groups may find that it doesn't suit their game for various reasons, like the potential for increased turn length or the effect it can have on one-shot games.

    Here are some alternative rules you can try if your group wants to rein in the power of the default SURGE rules, although it is recommended that you try the normal rules first.

    • Higher starting cost: The beacons start at a higher SURGE level. For example, they might start at SURGE level 2 instead of 0. This simple change is often used for one-shot games.
    • Partial Surge: When beacons SURGE , they get either a standard action, a standard movement, or a minor action, instead of all three. All other rules remain the same.
    • Restricted Surge. PCs can only SURGE once per scene, with a flat cost of 1d6+1 Stress. The human ancestry's Adrenaline trait instead grants resistance to Stress from SURGE, and the Rimeguard's ABSOLUTE ZERO limit break clears their own Stress and that of all allies in the scene and grants the affected characters resistance to all Stress for the rest of the scene.

    ACTIONS

    There are four types of actions characters can take: standard actions , reactions , minor actions , and free actions .

    Some abilities grant characters additional options when they use an action. For example, a beacon with the Rank 3 Brawler talent SUBMISSION gains a unique CHANNEL action. When they CHANNEL , they can choose to use the effects of SUBMISSION instead of one of their other CHANNEL abilities.

    Certain conditions, like STUNNED , limit the actions that a character can take.

    SIMULTANEOUS ACTIONS

    When multiple actions or effects would affect a character at the same time, such as at the beginning of their turn, the following rules apply:

    Actions and effects from other characters apply first:

    • Roll checks and saves first.
    • If there are multiple effects from one character, they choose the order in which they happen.
    • If there are effects from multiple characters, the GM decides the order.

    Self-imposed actions and effects apply second:

    • Roll checks and saves first.
    • You determine the order.

    Example: An enemy Cleaver is starting their turn adjacent to Dmitri, who is using the Warden job. Two effects are triggering at the start of the Cleaver's turn. The Cleaver's WHIRLWIND skill ends one of its benefits, and the Warden trait GRASPING VINES allows Dmitri to apply a negative effect to the Cleaver. Dmitri's effect will apply first, and the Cleaver's selfimposed effect will apply second.

    If Dhalia had an effect that was also triggering at the start of the Cleaver's turn, the GM would decide whether Dmitri's or Dhalia's effect would happen first.

    5: comBat Play aPPendiceS

    STANDARD ACTIONS

    This section lists the standard actions that you can perform on your turn, broken down by phase.

    - Phase 1: Bolster -

    PHASE BOLSTER

    Defend

    You gain FOCUS equal to your ARMOR+1D3 . Until the start of your next turn, attacks against you are made with +1 .

    Refresh

    PHASE BOLSTER

    Choose one of the following:

    • Spend a RECOVERY to regain all HP .
    • Clear all Stress.
    • Regain all MP .

    Then choose one of the following:

    • Reload all Reloading weapons/abilities.
    • Clear all Discord.
    • Clear a condition that wasn't caused by yourself.
    • Clear a condition on an adjacent ally that wasn't caused by them.

    - Phase 2: Channel -

    Channel

    PHASE CHANNEL

    You begin to enact a CHANNEL ability, the effect of which you can unleash in PHASE with the RELEASE action. This is the only way to trigger a channeled ability's RELEASE effect. Until you release it, you are considered to be channeling .

    While channeling, if you take any damage (after ARMOR ) or Stress not caused by yourself, you must pass a BULK save against the other character's SAVE TARGET . This is called a concentration save . On a failure, you lose concentration : you stop channeling and the ability fizzles.

    You can only channel one ability at a time, and you can't READY the CHANNEL action. You can stop channeling as a free action . If you don't make a standard movement this turn, you can do so when you RELEASE the ability this round.

    CHANNEL abilities are considered to be used at the time this action is taken, and any costs (e.g., MP ) must be paid at that time. Their effects, including choosing targets, only happen when they're released unless the ability specifically states they happen when channeling.

    - Phase 3: Skirmish -

    PHASE SKIRMISH

    Mark

    A character within your SCOPE and line of sight becomes MARKED .

    Search

    PHASE SKIRMISH

    Choose a character or object within SCOPE and pick one:

    • If they are HIDDEN , you make a contested MIND check against their AGILITY . On a success, they are no longer HIDDEN .
    • You learn the target's ability scores, attributes, and abilities.

    Volley

    PHASE SKIRMISH

    You make one of the following attacks:

    • Ranged attack: Make a ranged attack with an ability against a target within the ability's RANGE . Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result meets or exceeds the target's DODGE (or A-DEF for Aetheric attacks), it hits.
    • Improvised spell attack ( 1 MP ) : Make an Aetheric ranged spell attack against a character within SCOPE . Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result meets or exceeds the target's A-DEF , they take 2 STRESS .

    - Phase 4: Reposition -

    Hide

    PHASE REPOSITION

    You become HIDDEN .

    Rush

    PHASE REPOSITION

    Choose one of the following:

    • You move up to your SPEED .
    • Until the end of the turn, you ignore ENGAGEMENT and don't provoke reactions from movement.

    Fight

    - Phase 5: Brawl -

    PHASE BRAWL

    You make one of the following attacks:

    • Melee attack: Make a melee attack with an ability against a target within the ability's REACH . Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result equals or exceeds the target's DODGE (or A-DEF for Aetheric attacks), it hits.
    • Improvised weapon attack: Make a melee weapon attack against an adjacent target. Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result equals or exceeds the target's DODGE , they take 1D3 PHYSICAL .

    Grapple

    You make a grapple attack:

    • Grapple attack: Make a melee weapon attack against an adjacent character. Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result equals or exceeds the target's DODGE , you and the target are both GRAPPLED .

    Grapple attacks can be made while you are DISARMED (p. 62).

    Shove

    You make a shove attack:

    • Shove attack: Make a melee weapon attack against an adjacent target. Roll 1D20+GRIT . Y ou gain +1 for every SIZE you are larger than the target, or +1 for every SIZE smaller. If your result equals or exceeds the target's DODGE , choose one of the following:
    • You push them 1 space .
    • You knock them PRONE .

    Shove attacks can be made while you are DISARMED (p. 62).

    PHASE BRAWL

    PHASE BRAWL

    Release

    - Phase 6: Release -

    PHASE RELEASE

    You release an ability you are channeling, causing it to take effect. This is resolved as if you were taking a turn, following the rules for alternating turns between PCs and NPCs, but doesn't count as a turn. Instead of releasing an effect, you can continue channeling it and release it during PHASE in the next round. You can't release an ability if you are SILENCED .

    IMPROVISED ATTACKS

    VOLLEY and FIGHT allow characters to make improvised attacks . Improvised attacks are desperate attacks with whatever is nearby. An improvised weapon attack might use a nearby rock or even your bare hands, while an improvised spell attack might be an incredibly simple spell or a fragment of a more complex spell.

    Improvised attacks allow characters to always have the ability to attack and deal damage or Stress, even if their equipped abilities get destroyed. Improvised attacks don't require any training to use, and are usually inferior to equipped abilities.

    - Phase 7: Full Attack -

    Full Attack

    PHASE FULL ATTACK

    1/round , choose one of the following:

    • You use a Slow ability.
    • You perform any two of the following actions VOLLEY , FIGHT , SHOVE , or GRAPPLE . You can choose the same action twice, but not the same ability or the same linked pair of weapons.

    WHY CAN'T I USE THE SAME ABILITY/ACTION TWICE?

    To encourage variety. If you could use the same weapon multiple times, you might find yourself using your best weapon twice and only using secondary options when the primary one is destroyed. This way you need to use different options, and because of that, look for interesting synergies.

    WHAT DOES ATTACKING WITH TWO DIFFERENT WEAPONS LOOK LIKE?

    Rounds don't represent specific amounts of time. A round could be six seconds, minutes, or even days. This means you can describe it however you want. Maybe you wield one weapon in each hand. Maybe you swap them out. Maybe one gets stuck in your foe, and you draw another one. It's up to you, and doesn't matter mechanically.

    Delay

    - Phase 8: Delay -

    PHASE DELAY

    The last chance to take an action during this round. If you wanted to take an action but the phase had already passed, you can do so in this phase.

    Ready

    ANY PHASE

    You prepare your standard action at a later moment, turning it into a customizable reaction :

    • Select a trigger, which must be a specific action , movement , or reaction taken by any character.
    • Select your effect, which must be an action or minor action you can take during your current turn.
    • Until the start of your next turn, you can perform that readied action as a reaction when the trigger is met. If you haven't used your readied action by the start of your next turn, the action is lost. You can't use any other reactions while you have an action readied. You can forgo your readied action at any time.

    Example Readied Action

    REACTION

    Trigger: Any enemy moves outside of cover.

    Effect: I will VOLLEY at them.

    The READY action is used to set up an action for later. It can be used during any phase, but the action you set up for later is limited by the phase you are in and it must be an action you can currently take. For example, if you are DISARMED , you can't ready a VOLLEY action to attack with one of your ranged weapons, because the DISARMED condition is preventing you from making that weapon attack.

    REACTIONS

    In addition to actions, you can also perform reactions . Reactions are special actions that are performed in response to specific triggers, even on other characters' turns.

    You can perform one reaction per turn , but there's no limit on how many times a specific reaction can be used unless one is specified (e.g., 1/round).

    Some NPCs (typically elite enemies or mini-bosses) can take more than one turn in a round. For these NPCs, reaction limits like 1/round reset at the start of each of their turns and at the start of each new round.

    Each reaction has a trigger and an effect . The trigger is the event or occurrence that needs to take place for the reaction's effect to occur. The effect is what happens when the trigger is met.

    Unless otherwise noted, reactions resolve after their triggers. If a reaction's trigger is, 'when attacked,' the effect takes place after the attack has been resolved (including any damage). A reaction with a trigger of, 'when targeted,' or, 'when an attack is declared but before the roll is made,' on the other hand, goes into effect before the attack happens.

    Some effects, like forced movement (p. 55), don't provoke reactions even if a reaction's trigger would be met.

    These are the basic reactions available to all PCs. You can acquire additional reactions through equipped abilities.

    Counterattack FOCUS 1

    REACTION (1/ROUND)

    Trigger: You are hit by an attack from a character within the REACH of one of your abilities.

    Effect: You VOLLEY or FIGHT against that character with one of those abilities. Each attack roll can only be counterattacked once - multiple characters can't COUNTERATTACK in response to the same attack roll.

    Interpose FOCUS 1

    REACTION

    Trigger: An ally within RANGE 3 is targeted by an attack.

    Effect: You shift up to 2 spaces. If you end this movement next to the targeted ally, you can choose to become the target instead, even if you would otherwise not be a valid target. Each attack roll can only be interposed once - multiple characters can't INTERPOSE in response to the same attack roll.

    Opportunity Attack

    REACTION (1/ROUND)

    Trigger: An enemy begins a movement within the Reach of one of your abilities.

    Effect: You immediately VOLLEY or FIGHT against that character with one of those abilities.

    MINOR ACTIONS

    You can perform one minor action during your turn. Minor actions can be used during any phase.

    You can acquire minor actions through equipped abilities.

    FREE ACTIONS

    Free actions can only be taken during your turn, but you can perform any number of free actions during that turn (within reason).

    You can acquire free actions through equipped abilities.

    5: comBat Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game aPPendiceS

    5: comBat Play

    CHARACTERS AND OBJECTS

    In combat, everything on the battlefield can be separated into two categories: characters and objects .

    CHARACTERS

    PCs, Summons , and NPCs are all considered characters . As a general rule, characters are entities capable of taking some sort of actions, either personally or at the command of other characters.

    A character's abilities are considered part of that character, not separate objects or characters (unless explicitly stated otherwise).

    Allies and Enemies

    There are two sides or teams in every combat scene. The PCs are on one side and the NPC enemies are the other.

    Characters in a combat can be allies or enemies of the other characters. A character friendly to you or on the same side is an ally ; a character hostile to you or on the other side is an enemy . The same applies in reverse.

    You don't count as your own ally.

    OBJECTS

    An object is anything that isn't a character (or part of one). The terrain, parts of the environment, and deployed items (like Traps ) are all objects.

    Only things that fit this definition count as objects in the context of the rules. While we might describe a character's sword as an object in conversational language, it does not count as one in game terms because it is part of a character. You couldn't target or affect the sword with an ability that targets objects.

    Terrain

    Terrain is a specific subset of object that includes the environmental elements in a combat scene - trees, walls, rocks, and similar. Deployed objects , like Traps , are objects but don't count as terrain. Terrain is different from terrain features (p. 57), which are effects that modify terrain.

    The GM determines what counts as terrain and what doesn't.

    Interactable Objects and Terrain

    Some objects and terrain is interactive, meaning that characters can use actions on them for specific effects. Treasure chests , for example, require a minor action to open.

    ABILITY CHECKS AND SAVES

    In combat, players make ability checks and saves instead of skill checks .

    Ability check and save summary: Roll 1d20 + indicated ability score + or .

    Effects that prompt ability checks or saves indicate which ability score BULK , AGILITY , MIND , or MAGIC is used for the roll. Background skills, GRIT , and titles don't apply.

    To succeed on an ability check , you need a result of 10+.

    To succeed on a save , your result must equal or exceed the SAVE TARGET of the initiator, or 10 if not otherwise specified.

    TARGETING

    Abilities can either affect their user or target something else on the battlefield. Targeted abilities, like attacks, can be affected by obstacles or the layout of the battlefield.

    To target something with an ability or effect, the potential target must be:

    • within line of sight (p. 49);
    • within RANGE or REACH (p. 53); and
    • either a character, a space on the battlefield, or an object (p. 48).

    You can't attack yourself unless otherwise indicated.

    LINE OF SIGHT

    All abilities require a clear path to their target, known as line of sight , unless otherwise noted.

    Line of sight refers to a clear line of effect to a target. Walls and other sufficiently large objects can block line of sight, while smaller objects like crates or shrubs might provide cover instead of fully blocking line of sight (p. 50). While BEACON doesn't represent or measure vertical space, the SIZE of characters and objects is used as a way to determine line of sight.

    Line of sight is reciprocal. If you can draw line of sight to another character, then the second character also has line of sight to you.

    Line of sight does not literally require sight. For example, a character with no eyes can still draw line of sight, and a transparent wall of force still blocks line of sight even though you can see through it.

    Certain effects (like the Arcing and Homing tags) allow you to bypass the usual rules regarding line of sight. These tags not only allow you to draw line of sight in situations where you normally couldn't, but also allow for one-directional line of sight.

    Determining Line of Sight

    To determine line of sight, draw a straight line from the corner of one of the spaces you occupy to a corner of one of the spaces occupied by the target. If the line crosses a piece of hard cover that is a larger SIZE than both parties, then line of sight is blocked.

    Example: Y ou and your enemy are both SIZE 1 , and are on opposite sides of a SIZE 3 wall. Neither of you can draw line of sight to the other; however, if you have a weapon with the Arcing tag, you could shoot over the wall and the enemy still wouldn't have line of sight to you.

    FIGURE 1:

    Example A:

    Line of sight can be drawn and there is no cover.

    Example B:

    Line of sight cannot be drawn.

    Example C:

    Line of sight can be drawn, but cover applies.

    GettinG Started

    5: comBat Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game aPPendiceS

    5: comBat Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    COVER

    Objects on the battlefield can provide cover. Cover imposes on attacks and can block line of sight, depending on whether it is hard cover or soft cover .

    Cover is most often an object, but it can also be a zone (p. 53) or effect. Some abilities can create pieces of cover on the battlefield. These created pieces of cover count as objects.

    Pieces of cover have SIZES just like PCs. A SIZE 1 piece of cover fills 1 space, a SIZE 2 piece of cover fills a 2 2 space, and so on. Cover can sometimes cover more spaces than its SIZE would normally indicate; for example, a tall, thin column might only occupy 1 space despite being considered SIZE 3 , or a continuous wall surrounding a castle might be SIZE 2 , but occupy all the spaces around the castle.

    You can only benefit from cover if it's the same SIZE as you or larger. For example, a SIZE 2 character does not gain the benefits of cover from a SIZE 1 piece of cover.

    There are two types of cover: soft cover and hard cover . Soft cover and hard cover don't combine with each other. If you would gain the benefits of both soft and hard cover, you count as having hard cover.

    Soft Cover

    Soft cover grants +1 to attacks, but doesn't block line of sight.

    Soft cover is either cover that partly blocks a character, or isn't strong enough to fully shield them from attacks, like smoke or thin walls.

    Hard Cover

    Hard cover grants +2 to attacks and can block line of sight.

    Hard cover is cover that is large or strong enough to reliably block attacks, like thick walls.

    To benefit from hard cover, you must be adjacent to the source of cover. Otherwise, it only provides soft cover. Hard cover blocks line of sight.

    In Figure 1: Example B , the hard cover blocking line of sight means neither character has line of sight to the other. In Example C, they've positioned themselves so they have line of sight to each other, but cover applies. Because both characters are adjacent to the cover, they both benefit from hard cover. If one character was to move away from the cover, they would instead only benefit from soft cover, while their enemy retains hard cover for remaining adjacent to it.

    Determining Cover

    To determine if cover affects an attack, draw a line from the center of the space you occupy to the center of the target. If the line crosses any cover that is the same SIZE as the target or larger, your attack receives .

    Abilities with the Indirect or Homing tags ignore the effects of cover. Abilities with the Arcing tag, on the other hand, don't have their line of sight blocked by cover, but are still affected by the cover provides.

    FIGURE 2:

    Example A:

    The soft cover does not break line of sight, but both characters gain cover.

    Example B:

    The cover doesn't break line of sight because it isn't larger than both characters. Neither character is adjacent to the cover, so they gain soft cover instead of hard cover.

    Example C:

    As with B, but the smaller character gains hard cover because they are adjacent to the cover.

    Bypassing Cover

    You can ignore the effects of cover you are adjacent to, as long as you can aim over, through, or around said cover. You must be the same SIZE as or larger than the cover to aim over it. The GM has the final say on whether a character can bypass a specific piece of cover.

    As a guideline, you can ignore a number of spaces of cover equal to your SIZE when aiming over, through, or around said cover.

    FIGURE 3:

    Example A:

    Example B:

    Example C:

    The SIZE 2 character can choose to bypass the cover because they can shoot over it. They still benefit from hard cover against attacks from the SIZE 1 character.

    The SIZE 2 character can ignore the cover from the corner of the hallway because they can shoot around it. They still benefit from hard cover against attacks from the SIZE 1 character.

    Both characters can shoot over the pillar because they are the same SIZE as it; however, due to its length, the GM decides they can't bypass it since they can't shoot over the entire length of the pillar.

    ATTACKS

    Attack roll summary: Roll 1d20 + GRIT + or .

    Attacks are attempts by characters to hit and harm something with weapons, magic, or other means. To hit your target, your result must equal or exceed their defense (either DODGE or A-DEF , depending on the type of attack).

    Once an attack hits, any ' on-hit ' effects apply, with the attacker choosing the order when there are multiple such effects. Damage is the most common type of on-hit effect (p. 58), but many abilities have unique on-hit effects.

    ATTACK TYPES

    Attacks can be either melee attacks or ranged attacks . They can be further categorized as weapon , spell , support or skill attacks, depending on their source.

    Some abilities reference reaction attacks . These are attacks made with a reaction , like COUNTERATTACK .

    All attacks have a RANGE or REACH (or both), which indicates the maximum number of spaces within which an attack can be made. RANGE and REACH are measured from the edge of one of the attacker's spaces. At least one of the target's spaces must be within an attack's RANGE or REACH to be targeted by the attack.

    See pages p. 53 for more information on RANGE and REACH .

    Melee Attacks

    Melee attacks ignore cover (p. 50).

    Most melee attacks have a REACH , which indicates the range of the attack. REACH is also used for certain actions like OPPORTUNITY ATTACK .

    For example, the Dragon Rider's LONGINUS ability is a melee weapon . Therefore, attacks with it are considered melee weapon attacks. It has REACH 3 , which means it can be used to attack enemies up to 3 spaces away.

    This weapon gains Piercing when attacking targets at its maximum REACH .

    5: comBat Play runninG tHe Game

    aPPendiceS

    5: comBat Play

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game aPPendiceS

    Ranged Attacks

    Most ranged attacks have a RANGE , which indicates the range of the attack - the number of spaces within which it can be used to attack. Some ranged spell attacks list their RANGE as ' RANGE = SCOPE ' , which means that the Range is equal to the user's SCOPE .

    For example, the Phoenix's IMMOLATE ability is a ranged spell attack. Therefore, attacks with it are considered ranged spell attacks. It has a RANGE equal to the user's SCOPE , and can attack targets within that range.

    Immolate VOLLEY
    RANGED SPELL ATTACK 1MEMORY AETHERIC,
    INDIRECT RANGE = SCOPE 2 DISCORD

    On Hit: Choose one of the following:

    • Building Fire: If the target already has Discord , this attack deals 1D3+1 DISCORD instead of 2 .
    • Spontaneous Combustion: You can spend 1 MP to deal 1 DISCORD to all enemies in a BURST 1 AOE around the target.

    Some ranged attacks also have a REACH , but they are still considered ranged attacks. REACH , in these cases, is used for certain actions like OPPORTUNITY ATTACK , but doesn't change the attack to a melee attack.

    ATTACKS VS. ATTACK ROLLS

    An attack can be composed of either a single attack roll, or in the case of abilities that affect an area, multiple attack rolls.

    When an ability refers to an attack , it means all of the attack rolls made as part of that attack.

    Anything that mentions an attack roll references a single roll, even if the attack involves multiple attack rolls.

    AUTO-HIT

    Certain abilities auto-hit their targets, meaning they automatically hit with no attack roll. Abilities with an auto-hit are considered attacks even though the attack roll doesn't take place. INTERPOSE can still be used against auto-hit effects.

    Not every ability that deals automatic damage is an attack - only those that specifically state they auto-hit count as attacks.

    CRITICAL HITS

    On a result of 20+, an attack roll is a crit . Roll all damage dice twice and take the highest result.

    Critical hits do more damage than normal hits. Critical hits only affect damage rolls, not Stress or static damage (e.g., 2 PHYSICAL ).

    For example, if you critically hit with an attack that deals 2D6+2 PHYSICAL , you would roll 4d6, take the highest two, and add +2. If you rolled 4, 2, 6, and 3, you would use the 4 and 6.

    REROLL TABLE

    When making an attack, ability check, or save in combat , you can reroll the dice by using the Reroll Table . T o use the table, you choose one of the listed options and reroll all dice for one roll (including or ). Each option from the table can only be chosen once per round.

    You can choose to reroll a dice after rolling, but before it is resolved as a failure or a success. For example, rerolling to turn a missed attack into a hit doesn't mean that you actually missed the attack on the first try. As such, it doesn't prompt any effects that trigger on misses (like Reliable damage).

    REROLL TABLE

    Consequence Effect
    Strain You take 1d3 Stress.
    Endanger You become Marked. You cant use this option if you are Marked. This doesnt count as a condition that youve given yourself.
    Overextend You can only choose this option if you
    are adjacent to an enemy or within
    Reach of an enemys weapon. The
    enemy can choose one of the following,
    which resolves before you reroll:
    - They make an OPPORTUNITY ATTACK against you.
    - They deal 3 PHYSICAL to you as a reaction.

    RANGE, REACH, AND AREA OF EFFECT

    Many abilities have a RANGE or REACH , which indicates the maximum number of spaces within which it can be used. RANGE and REACH work in the same way, but some effects trigger based on one or the other, not both.

    RANGE and REACH are measured from the edge of one space to another. A target must have at least one of its spaces within an ability's RANGE (or REACH ) to be targeted by the ability.

    When an ability originates from a source larger than 1 space - a SIZE 2 character, for instance - the character using the ability decides which space to use as the point of origin.

    For example, two adjacent characters are within 1 space of each other, which means any ability with RANGE 1 or greater could target them.

    AREA OF EFFECT

    Abilities and effects with an area of effect (AOE) affect multiple targets or spaces.

    Abilities and effects with an AOE affect all targets within the indicated area. This area is the AOE. When making an AOE attack, you make attack rolls against each target in the area . Damage, on the other hand, is only rolled once , and applied to every affected target.

    There are several different types of AOE, including Line (which affects all targets in a straight line) and Blast (which affects all targets within a certain radius).

    If an effect lists a RANGE/REACH and an AOE, you can place the AOE's point of origin anywhere within the indicated RANGE/REACH . For example, if you have a RANGE 8, LINE 5 effect, you can draw the LINE 5 from any point within RANGE 8 and pointed in any direction.

    Zones

    Zones are persistent AOEs that have ongoing effects. For example, at rank 1, the Leyline Walker talent allows a character to create BLAST 1 zones that last until the end of the combat scene. Their AOE is BLAST 1 , but because they're zones the effect is ongoing.

    Standard Areas of Effect

    Blast X: Affects all targets within a radius of X spaces from the center space, including the center space . Cover and line of sight are calculated from the center space. Users can be affected by their own Blast .

    Close Blast X: As a Blast , but:

    • at least 1 space must be adjacent to the user
    • the user can't be in the area
    • cover and line of sight are calculated from the user.

    Burst X: Affects all targets within a radius of X spaces from the edge of the spaces occupied by the target, including the target's spaces but excluding the target itself. Cover and line of sight are calculated from the edge of the spaces occupied by the target. If a Burst forms a zone , the zone moves with the target.

    Line X: Affects all targets in a straight line with a length of X spaces and a width of 1 space, drawn directly away from you in any direction.

    5: comBat Play

    5: comBat Play

    MOVEMENT

    Characters can move around the battlefield in various ways, including with their standard movement, or using special types of movement like flight and teleportation .

    On your character's turn, you can use their standard movement to move a number of spaces equal to their SPEED . Certain abilities can also move characters at other times.

    Most of the time, entering an adjacent space counts as moving 1 space. This is its movement cost. But some effects, like difficult terrain (p. 56), can change the movement cost required to enter a space. Moving into these spaces requires characters to spend more of their total available movement. If a character doesn't have enough movement to enter a space, they can't move into that space.

    Characters can move in any direction, even diagonally, and can move into any adjacent space that isn't obstructed or impassable (see below). Movement is always made on the horizontal plane; characters can't move vertically up or down.

    To be considered moving, a character must move at least 1 space. Standing up from PRONE doesn't count as movement.

    Movement can be voluntary or involuntary . Voluntary movement is any movement that a character willingly takes. For example, a character taking their standard movement would consider the movement voluntary. Involuntary movement is not willingly taken by the character moving and is usually forced upon them, like forced movement (p. 55).

    LARGE CHARACTERS

    Characters of SIZE 2+ occupy multiple spaces, and therefore enter more than 1 space when moving. When a SIZE 2+ character moves into multiple spaces with different movement costs, use the highest cost. For example, a SIZE 2 orc occupies a 2 2 space on the battlefield. They want to move forward 1 space, which involves moving into two new spaces. One of these spaces is difficult terrain , which costs 2 spaces of movement to enter, and the other is a normal space that costs 1. The orc would have to spend 2 spaces of movement to move forward.

    SPLITTING UP MOVEMENT

    Voluntary movements can be split into any number of smaller movements punctuated by actions. Involuntary movements cannot.

    For example, a character with SPEED 6 could, when performing their standard movement , move 2 spaces, take an action, and then move 4 spaces.

    If you can make multiple attacks with one action, they can move in between each attack.

    Example: Dmitri wants to FULL ATTACK an enemy 3 spaces away. He has SPEED 6 , so he uses his standard movement , moving 2 spaces so that he is adjacent to the enemy. His first attack is with his club, and with a lucky damage roll he defeats that enemy!
