It's just important to know that, unlike in many games, BEACON doesn't require the GM to have already developed a setting.

    SAFETY TOOLS

    Safety tools are techniques and resources you can use in your game to ensure everyone playing is having fun and feeling safe.

    There are numerous things that can make someone feel unsafe, but in TTRPGs, unsafe situations often arise from the content of the game. For example, one player may not be comfortable with particularly gory descriptions, while another might want to avoid scenes involving drug use.

    Utilizing safety tools will help you find out which themes, topics, and scenes your players don't feel comfortable playing. It's important that you then respect

    those decisions .

    For example, a player mentions during session 0 that they have a phobia of spiders; knowing that giant spiders are a common enemy in fantasy stories, they ask that the game doesn't feature spiders. The players and GM all agree, even the player that wanted to make a spider-person character, because they respect the wishes of the player and don't want to make them feel unsafe during the game.

    A few sessions later, the GM forgets and begins introducing a combat scene with spiderlike enemies. Using the X-card safety tool, one of the players halts the action and reminds the GM about the request to not have spiders. The GM apologizes, redescribes the scene, and the game continues.

    This section summarizes several common safety tools. You can find a more robust list of safety tools in the TTRPG Safety Toolkit Guide by Kienna Shaw and Lauren-Bryant-Monk ( bit.ly/ttrpgsafetytoolkit ).

    The X-Card

    Created by John Stavropoulos

    The X-card is a card or object that anyone can touch or raise. Any time there is a scene that makes someone uncomfortable, they can raise or touch the card, at which point you stop that scene . Y ou can then discuss next steps, but the person who used the X-card doesn't have to explain their reasoning unless they want to.

    There are other variants on the X-card, including the Script Change options for fast-forwarding, pausing, and rewinding, designed by Brie Beau Sheldon.

    You can find out more about the X-card here: tinyurl. com/x-card-rpg

    You can find out more about the Script Change RPG Toolbox here: briebeau.itch.io/script-change

    Lines and Veils

    Created by Ron Edwards

    To use this technique, you and the players establish any number of 'lines' and 'veils' before the game begins.

    A line is a topic that should not appear in the game at all - a line that should not be crossed. For example, if someone places 'torture' as a line, torture does not happen in the game in any way, shape, or form.

    A veil is a topic that can be hinted at, but not shown directly. It gets put behind a veil or curtain. Things established as veils can take place in the game, but they won't be shown directly. For example, if someone places 'romantic scenes' as a veil, these scenes can happen in the story, but we're not going to show or dwell on them.

    If you or any of the players have a topic that you want to establish as a line or veil, you should mention it and track it in writing. Although they are established at the start of a game, lines and veils can be added, changed, or removed at any time during the course of a game.

    You can find out more about lines and veils here: rpg.stackexchange.com/questions/30906

    TONE

    One of the first things you should do as a group is establish the tone of your game. This helps everyone understand the sort of game they're getting into.

    The tone of a game is what lets everyone know what kind of story they're going to be telling. It can describe tone in many ways, from talking about specific story beats you want to see (betrayal, adventure, destiny) or emotions you want to invoke (hope, friendship) to referencing specific media examples that you want the story to be like (like Final Fantasy 7 meets The Fast and the Furious ).

    Tone can be established in a similar way to lines and veils. Every player, including the GM, can specify any tones they want included or excluded during session 0.

    Deciding on a tone doesn't completely exclude other content, but it sets the default expectation. Even if you're playing a gritty, serious game, that doesn't mean that there can't be moments of levity and comedy. It just means that these should be sprinkled around the gritty assumptions. If, over time, the comedy ends up becoming the focus of the game, the players and GM should discuss whether they want to shift the tone of the game to incorporate more comedy or move back to what they originally discussed.

    Tone is important for both players and the GM, as misunderstandings about a game's tone can cause friction between players. It's also okay not to have an idea for the tone until you begin designing your setting together.

    DESIGNING THE SETTING

    Unlike TTRPGs with pre-established settings for their games, BEACON assumes that each gaming group will create their own setting together. These settings are called Reflections , and they make up the infinite possible worlds of the Source .

    You can read more about the Source in Chapter 0: Introduction (p. 7), and find some prebuilt Reflections later in this section (p. 233).

    Designing the setting is a collaborative event that happens during session 0, and it's usually the last thing decided before people move onto creating their characters. Both the players and the GM get to have a say in what their Reflection is, although the GM can set guidelines or restrictions if they feel like it's necessary. For example, they might already have an idea for the Scourge, and want the players to design the rest of the Reflection with that particular Scourge in mind.

    There are a few elements common across the worlds of the Source. The following are true of every Reflection:

    • The world is filled with action and adventure .
    • There are beacons - people who are sources of great inspiration for others, whether they are heroes or villains.
    • There is a recurring threat - the Scourge .
    • Crystals hold some significance to the reflection or its inhabitants.
    • All things are composed of varying amounts of aether , magical elements that come in many varieties, including astral and lunar aspects.
    • Magic is widely available and has been combined with technology to create magitech devices.
    • Ruins dot the landscape, ready to be explored.

    Although these are true of each Reflection, their exact natures are left for you and the players to decide.

    RANDOM REFLECTIONS

    If you want to quickly generate a random Reflection, you can use the online Reflection generator here: https://www.pirategonzalezgames.com/resources

    The following sections discuss these elements and provide prompts and guidance for making those choices. It focuses on the following:

    • Themes: The topics that will be most important to your story.
    • Beacons: The role the PCs play in your Reflection.
    • The Scourge: The nature of your Reflection's recurring threat.
    • Crystals: The importance of crystals in your Reflection.
    • Aether and Magic: The way magic works in your Reflection.
    • Ruins and Dungeons: The nature of the ruins that wait to be explored.

    SCOPE OF STORIES

    Most stories are contained within a single Reflection, or might deal with a handful of Reflections at most. Few stories deal with the Source as a whole, and the vast scope of existence. If you do want to engage with this, here are some ideas for how you could do so:

    • Unification: Something is bringing Reflections together, or trying to combine everything into one truth - at the cost of limitless potential.
    • Separation: Something destroys the Source or seeks to do so. This would let the Reflections develop on their own, untethered to the truths within the Source.
    • Rogue Reflection: A rogue Reflection threatens the others. Perhaps this Reflection can consume others, growing more powerful in the process.
    • Darkness: Darkness is dimming the light of all beacons across the Source. Without beacons, the Reflections will grow dark and hope will be lost.

    THEMES

    The story you're going to tell will have certain themes in the form of prominent ideas, concepts, and other elements. These may not necessarily be things that are important in the Reflection itself, but are to the story your group is telling. For example, you might choose sacrifice as a theme. This means that sacrifices will be important to your story in some way. Maybe one of the beacons is expected to sacrifice themselves to seal the Scourge, or maybe the beacons have all been marked as sacrifices for the purposes of some great evil. In both cases, the theme of sacrifice is important to the beacons and their story, but isn't necessarily an objective truth about the Reflection itself.

    As a group, ask yourselves the following questions and then pick three themes for your Reflection, choosing from the below lists or making your own:

    • What themes do we want in our game?
    • What themes don't we want in our game?

    Like the tone, themes are a way for everyone to indicate the type of story they're interested in playing. For example, if everyone recently enjoyed watching a TV show about fighting corrupt institutions, someone might suggest corruption as one of the themes.

    EXAMPLE THEMES

    Balance Collecting Survival
    Artificial Scarcity Fallen Civilizations Hostile Environments
    The Number 13 Giants Bells
    Separation Darkness Optimism
    Right vs Wrong Unification Rain
    Sacrifice Protection Identity
    Redemption Embracing of the Scourge The Future
    Family History Freedom
    Graves Shame Pride
    Sea Transformation Electricity
    Boundaries Perseverance Revolution
    Music Vengeance New Horizons
    Reincarnation Cuteness Destiny
    Time Light Dreams
    Airships Mazes Nightmares
    Dinosaurs Poison Fire
    Stars Corruption Ice
    Destruction Illusions Floods
    Isolation Oblivion Justification
    The Past Holes Growth

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    BEACONS

    Heroes. Paragons. Chosen.

    Across all reflections, these legendary figures share a common name: beacon . The characters portrayed by players in your game are heroes like these.

    Beacons exist on each Reflection as inspirational or guiding figures. They can be heroes, villains, or anything else. What makes them truly special is that - one way or another - people look to them in times of trouble.

    For example, the beacons of one Reflection might be heroes from a doomed timeline, trying to prevent the destruction of their world, while those of another might be people with a unique ability to resist the poisoned air of the land beneath the clouds.

    As a group, ask yourselves the following questions and then decide on the role or nature of beacons in your Reflection, choosing from the below list or making your own:

    • What role do beacons serve in this Reflection?
    • How does one become a beacon?
    • What separates beacons from other people?

    EXAMPLE BEACON ROLES

    Reclaimers 11 Scapegoats
    Crystal Warriors 12 Summoners
    Dragon Hunters 13 Scions
    Mistwalkers 14 Living Spells
    The Last Survivors 15 Dreams Made Real
    The Blessed 16 The Shattered
    The Corrupted 17 Royals
    Reincarnated 18 The Chosen
    Vessels 19 The Eternal
    Voidwalkers 20 Shades

    SCOURGE

    The Scourge is a recurring threat - a guaranteed event in every Reflection. Its form and nature differs between Reflections, but it always exists (or did exist) in each. The Scourge may not always be the greatest threat facing a Reflection, but it is constant.

    The Scourge can be anything; the only consistent thing is that it's a threat of some sort. It's usually an entity (like a boss you can beat), but sometimes it might be an event, like two distinct worlds joining into one every 1,000 years.

    Many Scourges have powerful subordinates called heralds. These dangerous beings carry out the will of the Scourge or otherwise work to bring it about, leading armies and crushing beacons who stand against them.

    It is important to understand that the Scourge is a recurring threat , but not necessarily an evil . Every Reflection is unique, and sometimes a scourge is a force of evil, but sometimes it's not. Either way, it must be dealt with.

    Most games of BEACON revolve around Scourges, but sometimes the Scourge isn't the real threat of the story.

    As a group, ask yourselves the following questions and on decide what the Scourge is, choosing from the below list or making your own:

    • What is the Scourge?
    • Why is the Scourge recurring?
    • How long has the Scourge been a threat?
    EXAMPLE SCOURGES EXAMPLE SCOURGES EXAMPLE SCOURGES EXAMPLE SCOURGES
    1 The manifestation of dying wishes 11 The Danger Behind the Final Seal
    2 You,from another timeline 12 The New Dawn
    3 Advancement at all costs 13 The Blight
    4 The hubris that doomed us all 14 The Masked Prisoner
    5 The evils of wealth 15 The Blood Prayer
    6 He Who Was Shattered 16 The Spiral of Death
    7 The Nightmare 17 The Titan
    8 The Jailer 18 The Warmonger
    9 That Which Lives in the Space Between 19 The Deep Horror
    10 The Rejoining 20 The Meteor

    RUINS AND DUNGEONS

    Dungeons and ruins dot the landscape of each Reflection, enticing heroes to enter their dangerous domains.

    These places tell stories. They were once meant to inspire awe or fear, and are now crumbling shadows of their former self.

    Ruins serve as a convenient way to house items that are important to your story. A classic RPG trope is that the item necessary to defeat the big bad boss is housed in a ruin.

    Ruins mean different things and have different origins across Reflections. In one Reflection they may be the crumpled castles and cities of a once prosperous empire, while in another they're abandoned flying laboratories from an advanced civilization that mysteriously disappeared. These would both be considered the dungeons of their respective Reflections, even though one of them doesn't match the dictionary definition of a dungeon.

    As a group, answer the following questions and then decide the origin and nature of ruins:

    • What civilization left ruins behind? Are they still around?
    • What is a common feature among these types of ruins?
    • What unique things can be found in these ruins, that can't be found anywhere else?
    • Why are ruins still being discovered today?
    EXAMPLE RUIN ORIGINS EXAMPLE RUIN ORIGINS EXAMPLE RUIN ORIGINS EXAMPLE RUIN ORIGINS
    1 Technologically advanced civilization 11 Impressions from other Reflections
    2 Dead dragons 12 Natural disaster
    3 Sunken landmasses 13 'Aliens'
    4 Places abandoned to the Scourge 14 Remains of a cursed civilization
    5 The pinnacle of our civilization 15 Remains of a defeated civilization
    6 We have no idea and it scares us 16 Living dungeons
    7 Risen from the sea 17 Wounds in reality
    8 Fallen from the sky 18 Myths of old
    9 Formed from sites of death 19 Graves of the gods
    10 Places that don't exist yet 20 The world we left

    CRYSTALS

    Crystals hold a unique role in every Reflection. In some, they contain raw magical energy. In others, they are used as a form of currency. There are infinite possibilities.

    That the Source is typically described as a crystal and crystals have significant roles in each Reflection can't be a coincidence.

    As a group, ask yourselves the following questions and then decide what role crystals serve:

    • What is the role of crystals?
    • How and where are crystals formed?
    • How are crystals obtained?

    EXAMPLE NATURE/USES OF CRYSTALS

    Job Crystals 11 Removing Limits
    Airship Fuel 12 Summoning Fuel
    Ammunition 13 Planar Travel
    Money 14 Transformation
    Prayers 15 Dragon Food
    God-Slaying Power 16 Resurrection
    Monster Creation 17 Soul Entrapment
    Distilled Aether 18 Artifact Creation
    Artificial Stars 19 Manifest Powers
    Unbreakable Walls 20 Power Source

    10: Game maSter'S Guide

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    AETHER AND MAGIC

    Magic exists in every Reflection, although its use varies wildly. Some Reflections are rife with magic, while it is rare or hard to use in others.

    Aether is the general term for energies that can be harnessed to produce magical effects. It can be found in everything, including people.

    Regardless of how magic works in your Reflection, player characters should always have access to it in combat play. The game is designed around the idea that every beacon is able to access and use magic.

    As a group, ask yourselves the following questions and then decide how magic works:

    • What can magic do, and what can't it do?
    • How common is magic?
    • How do people use magic? Are there different styles or traditions of magic?
    • What is the cost of using magic?
    • How has magic affected the world?

    EXAMPLE DESCRIPTORS FOR MAGIC

    Abundant 11 Overflowing
    Elements 12 Regional
    Draconic 13 Bloodlines
    Structured 14 Dust
    Innate 15 Sun
    Technological 16 Moon
    Psionic 17 Pacts
    Rare 18 Bonds
    Forbidden 19 Spirits
    Mandatory 20 Wild

    OTHER QUESTIONS

    There are some other questions you can use to further flesh out your Reflection:

    • How do people live? Are there cities and towns, are people nomadic, or something else?
    • How do people travel long distances?
    • What is the fastest mode of travel?
    • What species exist or are commonly encountered? Humans, elves, machina, or others?
    • What supernatural creatures exist? Are there vampires, werewolves, demons, and so on?
    • What currencies do people use?
    • Do deities exist, or do people believe they exist?
    • What great disaster is still in everyone's mind?
    • What secret about the world do people not know?

    EXISTING REFLECTIONS

    To assist with the creative process and provide potential quick entry points to the game, this section details some example Reflections you can use or from which you can take inspiration.

    CRYSTAL WARRIORS

    SUMMARY

    Crystal warriors are those people that can attune to job crystals , quickly gaining access to a wealth of knowledge and power. They are the destined heroes who must fight against the Scourge when it arises, defeating it and bringing a time of peace. Unknown to these warriors, however, they are perpetuating a cycle of death.

    BEACONS

    In this Reflection, beacons are known as crystal warriors . They have a special aptitude for job crystals, items that grant special abilities and powers. Although anyone can use a job crystal, crystal warriors can do so with great ease, and can also access and use multiple job crystals.

    In times of peace, crystal warriors are free to do as they please; however, when a new Scourge arises, they are the only ones that can do battle with it and its heralds. It can be a shock to some crystal warriors to find out that the fate of the world rests on their shoulders.

    SCOURGE

    After each defeat, the Scourge lies dormant, reforming and building its strength over generations. Once the Scourge is close to reawakening, it sends out heralds to gather information and start setting plans into motion. The appearance of these heralds also signals to the people of the Reflection that a new Scourge is at hand, and the crystal warriors must be brought together.

    The Scourge is different every time it appears, but there are common visual themes. Work with your players to decide these themes. They might include a cold aura, multiple eyes, aquatic adaptations, or a humanoid form.

    You can use the below table to randomly generate the unique elements of the Scourge's latest manifestation:

    SCOURGE'S ELEMENT

    Undeath 5 Fire 9 Divine
    Time 6 Cold 10 Water
    Corruption 7 Storm 11 Space
    Poison 8 Earth 12 Technology

    ROLE OF CRYSTALS

    Job crystals are magical artifacts that contain knowledge about how to perform specific tasks. Attuning to such a crystal grants access to that knowledge, and repeated use of a job crystal allows the attuned person to access the full depths of knowledge stored inside.

    Anyone can attune to a job crystal. A blacksmith might use one to gain access to schematics from an age long past, or a former tax collector could start a new life as a doctor, completely dependent on the job crystal to do anything.

    Unknown to most of the Reflection's inhabitants, job crystals are formed from people that are defeated by the Scourge and its heralds.

    MAGIC AND AETHER

    Everything in this Reflection is filled with aetheric energy. Aether is one of the key forces of the world, like gravity. There are many types of aether - called aspects - including fire, cold, light, dark, and many others.

    Living creatures contain many of these different aetheric aspects at once, which come together to form a stable balance in their bodies. From this natural aether, and the aether in the air, magical effects can be produced.

    Most living creatures are sensitive to aetheric imbalances in their body, and these imbalances can cause illness or even death. Fortunately, effects that quickly alter aetheric balances are rare. Elementals, celestials, and other creatures are much more sensitive to even minor imbalances, as their bodies are entirely made of aether.

    RUINS

    The Eldeen Empire once ruled the world, pioneers of technology and magic. The empire's inventions were astounding, many centuries beyond what anyone can do today.

    Eventually, however, the Eldeen Empire fell into ruin. Scholars don't share a consensus on the catalyst for this downfall, or if there were many catalysts. Regardless, all that's left now are the ruins of the once-great empire.

    Eldeen ruins are found all over the world, including inhospitable places like beneath the ocean, inside volcanoes, and even on the moon. These ruins can be incredibly dangerous due to their defenses, the projects their occupants were working on, or even the locations in which they were built; however, every scrap of knowledge brought back from the depths of an Eldeen ruin is incredibly valuable.

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    THEMES

    Cycles: This Reflection is shaped around the inevitable cycle of the Scourge's rise and fall. The Scourge emerges, causes destruction and chaos, is defeated by crystal warriors, recedes into the background for just long enough to be forgotten, and arises once more.

    Sacrifice: Crystal warriors have a duty to stand against the Scourge, as only a crystal warrior can defeat it. Unbeknownst to most, however, those crystal warriors defeated by the Scourge or its heralds eventually become job crystals themselves. In addition, whichever crystal warrior deals the blow that defeats the Scourge is automatically sacrificed, their life essence drawn from their body and used to 'destroy' the Scourge. Essentially, their body becomes a large job crystal, which then serves as the host for the next Scourge.

    This is why crystal warriors are - unknown to them - so important to the Scourge. It wants the strongest warriors to fight it, so that if it is defeated, it can use their killer's body and skills as its next host.

    Accept or Defy Fate: Many stories about crystal warriors revolve around them discovering and coping with the fact that at least one of them will die defeating the Scourge. Those that look for an alternative might discover the dark truth about the cycle, and instead look for ways to break the cycle altogether. Either way, the Scourge has to be dealt with, and time is ticking.

    DETAILS

    In this Reflection, magic and magitech are widely available. Airships, trains, and other fantastical elements are common, and amazing structures have been built in ages both past and present.

    Because of the widespread availability of magic, technology, and job crystals, communities can grow large and take care of the people who live within them.

    This Reflection is designed around the 'rule of cool' . Don't worry about realism and physics - just focus on telling engaging stories full of cool things.

    COLOSSUS

    SUMMARY

    The denizens of Reflection: Colossus live in cities built into the bodies of massive, wandering mechanical beings - the colossi. One of these colossi has begun to attack other colossi, and the beacons - the very dreams of the colossi - must face this danger.

    BEACONS

    Beacons are the dreams of the colossi. When a colossus faces a serious obstacle or problem, they draw upon their stores of crystals to manifest a solution from their dreams in the form of a beacon.

    Beacons have unique connections to the colossi that dreamt them, but they are their own independent entities. Some beacons rebel against the task they were created for, while others embrace it.

    Colossi don't create beacons lightly. Once a beacon is created, they have no control over their agent, and no way to reclaim the resources used to create them.

    SCOURGE

    The colossi roam the world, searching for deposits of crystals that they consume for energy. One colossus has learned that it is easier to attack other colossi than hunt for food alone. This is the Scourge.

    This colossus is known as 'the City of the Dead' , for the massive city built into their body. No living creatures can be found in this city, and legends hold that the colossus killed their own inhabitants when they dared to try to gain control of it.

    ROLE OF CRYSTALS

    Crystals are a source of food and energy for the colossi. These beings consume as much as they can, which seems to be passively absorbed by the magics and machinery that make up their body. Many cities are home to crystal hunters - people that seek out large deposits to which they can lead their colossus.

    MAGIC AND AETHER

    Magic is rare in this Reflection and requires crystals to fuel spells. Using magic is a long, complicated, and laborious process, and since it uses the same crystals that the colossi eat, the people living on them are hesitant to use them.

    Beacons, however, are innately magical and can easily use magic. Spells that would require a team of regular arcanists can be cast with a wave of a beacon's hand.

    RUINS

    Abandoned colossi and those returning from the underground are the ruins of this Reflection. Beacons are needed to ensure each colossus is safe for settlement.

    THEMES

    Journey: The movements of the colossi are unpredictable, and the people that live atop them are subject to their whims. Colossi occasionally burrow underground, where they can go missing for years or even centuries, before rising again from the underworld.

    Dreams: Beacons are formed from the dreams of the colossi, so dreams and the meanings of dreams are important themes in this Reflection.

    Purpose: Beacons are created for specific purposes. What happens when that purpose is fulfilled, or what happens if someone can't or won't accomplish the task for which they were created?

    DETAILS

    Most of the time, each beacon is from their own colossus, although it is possible for multiple PCs to be from the same one.

    When the players describe and introduce their characters, ask them to also describe the colossus that dreamt them, and the problem they were dreamt to solve.

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    THE SOUL GUARD

    SUMMARY

    Dangerous monsters arise constantly from the Mistlands, a place saturated with the souls of those killed in a long-forgotten cataclysm. One group - the Soul Guard - trains to fight these monsters and protect the last standing city, Novissimum.

    BEACONS

    The leading members of the Soul Guard are the beacons of this Reflection. Each beacon leads a branch of the Soul Guard. Each of these branches has its own specialty, whether it be city defense, research, or Mistland expeditions.

    SCOURGE

    Based on what the Soul Guard has learned, the Scourge is an intelligent creature from the Mistlands that seeks to cause another cataclysm. By doing so, it hopes to expand the borders of the Mistlands.

    In truth, however, the Scourge's motivations are deeper than what they have been told. It will take everything the heroes of the Soul Guard have to find the truth.

    ROLE OF CRYSTALS

    Crystals are one of the only things that keep back the mist from the Mistlands. The largest crystals are built into the walls of Novissimum, keeping a wide area safe. Crystal posts have been placed along a few roads to improve visibility, but they're not strong enough to keep the monsters away.

    MAGIC AND AETHER

    The mist from the Mistlands has a dampening effect on aether, making it harder to use. Monsters are also highly resistant to magic, their skin immediately dispersing weak spells.

    To counteract this, the Soul Guard uses weapons infused with incredibly high levels of aether. The aetheric density of these weapons makes them able to pierce monstrous defenses, and mages can use these weapons as foci that enhance their spells to the point where they can harm monsters.

    RUINS

    The Mistlands are pocketed with ruins from the cataclysm. The closest ruins are abandoned sections of the Novissimum, lost to the mist. However, deeper in the Mistlands reside ruins from other cities, whose history tells a different story than the Soul Guard were lead to believe.

    THEMES

    Survival: Stories in this Reflection start with a focus on the threat of the Mistlands - either the monsters that come from within or the dangers of exploring it.

    Responsibility: As leaders of the Soul Guard, the beacons have to cope with the challenges of politics and bureaucracy, which intensify as they discover the truth about the cataclysm, the Mistlands, and the history of Novissimum.

    The Past: The inhabitants of the Novissimum have been told a misleading or false history. The true nature of their world's past is for the GM to decide, but important powers want to keep that past buried.

    DETAILS

    Novissimum is the final bastion of civilization - the only known urban structure to survive the calamity that nearly destroyed this Reflection. Beyond the walls of the city lie the Mistlands, an endless landscape filled with dangerous horrors.

    The truth of this Reflection's history lies in the Mistlands. Troubling clues are being brought into the light as the Scourge puts its plans into motion.

    The exact history of this Reflection is for each group to decide, but one truth is this: The city is not alone, and the actions its people took during the calamity were not as benign as history says.

    DESIGNING A HUB

    Once you've designed your Reflection, the next step is to create a Hub for the beacons. The Hub will be their base of operations - something like a guildhall, personal airship, or castle. It provides them with a place to rest, repair equipment, and replenish their resources.

    It's important for the beacons to have a Hub because this game assumes they will always have access to resources between quests. They don't need to worry about maintaining access to their unlocked equipment and abilities - they're always available at the Hub.

    The Hub also serves as a great way to introduce friendly NPCs, like a blacksmith who can repair weapons or a cheerful treasurer who makes sure the beacons can fund their adventures.

    The players and GM build the Hub together: the players make several decisions as a group, and the GM provides guidance and answers questions.

    STARTING WITHOUT A HUB

    You can decide to delay the acquisition of a Hub so the beacons don't start with one; however, the GM should make sure the beacons get one as soon as possible.

    BUILDING THE HUB

    Designing a Hub involves choosing features , drawbacks , and a theme . These describe important parts of the Hub, and help the players understand how the Hub looks and fits into the Reflection. These aspects are intentionally open-ended so that the players and GM can fill out the details themselves.

    A well protected Hub, for example, could simply have sturdy walls, or it could have automated magitech guards patrolling at all times.

    Begin by choosing two beneficial features for the hub from the list below or making your own.

    FEATURES FEATURES FEATURES FEATURES
    1 Mobile 4 Long history
    2 Well protected 5 Highly valuable
    3 Secret location 6 Dedicated support staff

    Next, choose two drawbacks or make your own.

    DRAWBACKS DRAWBACKS DRAWBACKS
    1 4 Prone to monster infestations
    2 5 Hard to get to
    3 6 Terrible reputation

    Then choose a theme or make your own.

    THEME THEME
    1 Mechanical 4 Magical
    2 Natural 5 Aquatic
    3 Urban 6 Unnatural

    Finally, decide on a name for your Hub. Examples include:

    • the Cloudwalker
    • Skyhold
    • the Strolling Sands
    • the Ragnarok

    EXAMPLE HUB

    The Cloudwalker is mobile and well protected , but has high operating costs and a terrible reputation . It has a mechanical theme.

    The Cloudwalker is an old combat airship showing signs of its age. Its armor plates are rusty and stained, but still sturdy. Keeping an airship in the air is already expensive, and keeping a relic like the Cloudwalker in working condition is even more so.

    In its history as a combat airship, the Cloudwalker was used in a number of terrible assaults. Its distinctive silhouette brings fear to those who see it and remember the horrors it once brought.

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    HUB UPGRADES

    The Hub can be upgraded during your game to improve it or make it feel more like home. Some upgrades provide narrative benefits, like the caf , while others provide mechanical benefits, like the runeforge . Some example Hub upgrades are provided below, but the GM can also create custom upgrades to suit the needs of the players.

    Each upgrade has a GOLD cost to acquire it, and some can be enhanced (for a price) to improve their effects. Some can even be enhanced multiple times. The descriptions list the increased benefits of enhanced up-

    ALCHEMY LABORATORY

    COST

    ENHANCE

    The Alchemy shop is always available during downtimes. The group can acquire 2/3/4 GOLD worth of supplies from the alchemist shop (p. 347) for free between each quest without performing a downtime activity.

    CAF

    COST

    ENHANCE

    Your caf attracts people of one type: random, interesting, or important.

    Each enhancement adds an additional type of people attracted from the list.

    CASINO

    COST

    ENHANCE

    During each downtime, each PC can wager any amount of GOLD and roll 1d6. On a 1-3, they lose the GOLD wagered. On a 4-6, they win, keeping their wager and gaining an equal amount of GOLD .

    This can be done multiple times per downtime, but every time the range of win results decreases by 1 (from 4-6 to 5-6, then 6).

    The casino can be enhanced once, which increases the starting range to win by 1 (from 4-6 to 3-6).

    grades with a slash. For example, '2/3/4' means that the upgrade begins at 2 and can be enhanced to 3, then 4.

    The beacons can pool their GOLD together to purchase upgrades and enhancements. The GM may also allow for other forms of payment or cost reductions. For example, if the beacons save a blacksmith's life, the GM might allow them to reduce the cost of the forge upgrade by -2 GOLD , if they can convince that blacksmith to join them.

    DRESSING ROOM

    COST

    ENHANCE

    The leatherworker/clothier shop is always available during downtimes. The group can acquire 2/3/4 GOLD worth of SUPPLIES from the leatherworker/clothier (p. 350) for free between each quest without performing a downtime activity.

    FORGE

    COST

    ENHANCE

    The blacksmith shop is always available during downtimes. The group can acquire 2/3/4 GOLD worth of SUPPLIES from the blacksmith (p. 349) for free between each quest without performing a downtime activity.

    JUNKYARD

    COST

    ENHANCE

    The engineer shop is always available during downtimes. The group can acquire 2/3/4 GOLD worth of SUPPLIES from the engineer (p. 352) for free between each quest without performing a downtime activity.

    KITCHEN

    COST

    ENHANCE

    The tavern is always available during downtimes. The group can acquire 2/3/4 GOLD worth of SUPPLIES from the tavern (p. 354) for free between each quest without performing a downtime activity.

    COST

    LIBRARY

    ENHANCE

    You have access to broad, secret, or detailed information.

    Additionally, players are free to look up general NPC type and template information during combat. This doesn't grant them knowledge of the current status or abilities of the specific NPCs they're facing.

    MEDICAL BAY

    COST

    ENHANCE

    A place of healing. PCs can use it to quickly heal minor-to-moderate injuries, and stabilize major ones.

    PORTAL

    COST

    ENHANCE

    A portal magically connects your Hub to another location you can easily access.

    Each enhancement lets you connect another location.

    RUNEFORGE

    COST

    5

    -

    ENHANCE

    Between each 1 RESIDUUM .

    quest,

    each

    beacon

    gains

    STOCKED CAMP

    COST

    ENHANCE

    During Short Rests, beacons can switch pieces of equipment or techniques with different ones. Equipment or techniques that are destroyed or have no remaining charges can't be switched. Each beacon can do this 1/2/3 times per quest.

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    TELLING YOUR STORY

    By this point, you will have completed session 0. With your Reflection and Hub decided, you're ready to play the game. Next, everyone creates their characters (see p. 11) and then you can start to tell your story!

    BUILDING CAMPAIGNS

    Your campaign is the greater story that you and your players are playing through together, usually set on a single Reflection. All the quests, narrative scenes, and combat scenes you and your players will experience are part of this campaign.

    Most campaigns revolve around confronting their Reflection's Scourge. This might involve defeating it, sealing it away, or even trying to break the cycle of the Scourge forever.

    When you create your Reflection in Session 0, you will probably start formulating ideas for the outline of a campaign. Keep those discussions in mind as you plan out the details of the campaign.

    This section presents some tips for building a campaign and the quests that make it up.

    LENGTH

    When planning a campaign, think about how long you want it to last. Because character levels are tied to quests, they're a great way to measure campaign length.

    Are you and the players looking for a short commitment? Maybe plan on playing for 3-6 character levels. A longer campaign can go all the way up to level 12.

    While it's possible to go up to level 12, your campaign doesn't need to last this long. It's perfectly possible to tell a story in a shorter time frame, and most characters can feel complete well before level 12.

    STARTING POINT

    Next, consider what level you want the beacons to start at. By default, they start at level 1, and this is recommended for new players; however, if you have an experienced group, they might want to start at a higher level, and that's fine.

    It's important to note that higher levels in BEACON doesn't necessarily equate to stronger characters. Higher-level beacons do get more ability points and GRIT , but mostly they just get more options and complexity, not raw power. Even at level 1, beacons are heroes. They're the main characters. A low level doesn't automatically mean they're untrained commoners.

    CHARACTER CONNECTIONS

    Incorporate elements from your PCs' background skills into the campaign. Tie these characters and their stories to the broader story of the campaign, and keep doing so throughout.

    Each story beat that takes place in the campaign should be connected to at least one of the PCs.

    ONE STEP AT A TIME

    You don't need to plan out your entire campaign ahead of time. It's good to have a rough outline of where you might want it to go, but planning out every beat ahead of time can sometimes be a hindrance.

    During the course of your campaign, your players will take actions that deviate from your planned story. That's fine! It's completely normal, and happens in most campaigns. That's why you don't want to waste time and energy planning out every step of the campaign ahead of time, because you will have to change those plans at some point anyway.

    Plan a few steps or levels ahead, stay flexible, and have an outline of where you want the story to go next.

    BUILDING QUESTS

    BEACON revolves around quests . The protagonists of your story will undergo a series of quests, pursuing their goals across both narrative and combat play. After each quest, they have a period of downtime before going on the next one.

    Quests are like chapters in a story, with combats as the high-action peaks of that story. Quests usually contain one to four combat scenes, with narrative scenes sprinkled throughout.

    Quests should always further the main campaign, even if not directly. Perhaps a seemingly unrelated quest allows the beacons to learn an important fact about the Scourge, or help them take out an important agent of the Scourge.

    QUEST STAGES

    A story typically has four stages: an inciting incident , rising action , a climax , and then the conclusion . This is a useful framework for planning quests. All you need to do is come up with ideas for each of those four stages, and then figure out where your one to four combat scenes fit in:

    • Inciting incident: This is the catchy introduction to the quest's story, which coincides nicely with the beacons' preparations for the quest. You might either tell the players what's going on, or use cutscenes to explain the situation.
    • Rising action: This is the buildup of the story, defined by ever-escalating stakes and tension. Each scene builds on those that have come before. This is usually the longest part of the quest, and where most combat scenes happen.
    • Climax: This is the highest point of the story - the culmination of all the prior scenes. The climax is often a final fight or confrontation.
    • Conclusion: This is the wrap-up of the story, where the repercussions of the beacons' actions shine through. This usually leads directly into downtime.

    QUEST IDEAS

    Here are some simple ideas that you can use or modify for your own quests. Each quest contains examples for each of the four quest stages identified above.

    Dug Too Deep

    Summary: Some miners dug too deep, and now the mine is swarming with monsters.

    Inciting Incident: The miners unearthed a hole with no bottom. When they sent someone to explore, their animated skeleton was the only thing that returned. Monsters began to appear in the mine and the miners reported hallucinations before they abandoned it altogether.

    • Rising Action: The PCs must venture into the bottomless pit and deal with the source of these monsters or find a way to plug the hole for good.
    • Climax: The beacons must evade a giant monster, riding mine carts in a thrilling chase before the collapsing mine traps them inside!
    • Conclusion: The mine's closed for good, but that's probably a good thing considering the size of the monster that chased the beacons.

    Escort Cargo

    • Summary: Eris Brittam, a historian and collector of antiques, needs a shipment of important cargo to be protected during transport.
    • Inciting Incident: A group of pirates recently attacked the shipment. The next stage of the journey is the most dangerous, and the pirates will definitely attack again. The cargo will next be loaded onto an airship or train.
    • Rising Action: The beacons must fend off numerous pirate attacks. As the cargo gets closer to its destination, the pirates grow more desperate.
    • Climax: Runaway train/ship! If the pirates can't have the cargo, no one can! The beacons must defeat the pirate leader and regain control of the train/ ship before it crashes!
    • Conclusion: The beacons see what happens when the cargo reaches its destination and are rewarded by Eris Brittam.

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    Kidnapped Royal

    Summary: A prince or princess has been captured and must be rescued! The royal family has an idea who might have done it, but the real reason might be surprising

    Inciting Incident: The beacons arrive at the castle the morning after the royal was kidnapped. The castle is in a state of panic as they search for the missing person, and no one will deal with the beacons until they are returned.

    Rising Action: The beacons identify the kidnapper and where they went. They must make their way to where the royal is being held before the kidnapper can escape.

    Climax: The beacons confront the kidnapper. If the kidnapper was in the wrong, the beacons must fight them and their companions. If the situation is more complicated, they must confront the true threat.

    Conclusion: The beacons are rewarded by whoever they supported, and are offered support in their next task.

    Kill the Dungeon

    Summary: A living, growing dungeon has been unearthed. Its rooms expand like tree roots, weakening the ground and releasing monsters onto the surface. It must be stopped.

    Inciting Incident: Monster attacks have been on the rise lately, but with no obvious source. One day a sinkhole swallows up part of a city, revealing an expanding dungeon beneath. Architects confirm that where the dungeon is now, there once were sewers. The dungeon is growing.

    Rising Action: The beacons venture into the dungeon, encountering the monsters and traps that spawn inside of it. They find signs of the life and intelligence that is the dungeon itself.

    Climax: The dungeon focuses its ability to create monsters to forging a powerful body for itself. This living manifestation of the dungeon clashes with the beacons, attempting to purge its body of the invading heroes!

    Conclusion: If the beacons win, they can kill the dungeon and stop it from growing any further. If they lose, it will grow unchecked.

    Night of the Dead

    Summary: A town is under siege by the undead, who rise every night but turn to ash when the sun rises.

    Inciting Incident: The beacons receive a direct request for aid from the townsfolk. The people of the town need help identifying the source of the undead invasion and putting a stop to it. They lose more people every night and will soon be overrun.

    Rising Action: The beacons help the townsfolk temporarily strengthen their defenses, then go hunting for the source of the undead. They trace it back to the shadowy forest nearby.

    Climax: The beacons make their way through the forest to confront the foul necromancer, a powerful young mage who was exiled from the town as a child.

    Conclusion: The beacons either defeat the necromancer or convince them to stop. The townsfolk are relieved to be safe once more.

    Remove the Corruption

    Summary: A corrupt political leader has been rallying the populace against the beacons and their efforts.

    Inciting Incident: The corrupt leader calls for the imprisonment of the beacons. A mob of deceived citizens attack the beacons.

    Rising Action: The beacons have to avoid drawing attention to themselves. They must figure out how to remove the corrupt leader and get proof of their corruption.

    Climax: The corrupt leader reveals their master plan in a villainous monologue, and sets their lackeys upon the beacons! The heroes must capture them before they can destroy the evidence.

    Conclusion: If the beacons get the evidence, they can regain their good standing. If not, they are forever branded as outlaws and criminals.

    BUILDING COMBAT SCENES

    There are a number of decisions a GM has to make when preparing a combat scene. For example, they need to:

    • decide how difficult the combat will be (p. 243)
    • create a battle map for the combat and populate it with terrain features
    • decide on the combat's battle plan (p. 244). For example, is it a simple Elimination scene in which the PCs just have to defeat all the enemies, or is it more involved, like an Assassination scene?
    • decide how many NPCs will be in the combat scene, what their NPC types are, and whether they have any templates (p. 259).

    The rest of this section covers these decision points, and Chapter 11: Non-Player Characters (p. 259) contains the full list of NPCs, templates, and their rules.

    SCENE DIFFICULTY

    A combat scene's difficulty is one way for a GM to customize a fight. The main way to adjust a combat's difficulty is by increasing or decreasing the number of enemies within it.

    The first step in deciding how many NPCs should be present in a combat scene is to determine your NPC budget . T o do this, take the number of PCs that will be participating in the fight and multiply that number by 1.5. For example, if you have 4 PCs, your NPC budget will be 6 (4 1.5 = 6).

    NPC budget = # of PCs 1.5

    Certain battle plans will modify this NPC budget. The Survival battle plan, for example, doubles your NPC budget. If your normal NPC budget would be 6, for example, it would be doubled to 12 in a Survival combat scene.

    Every NPC you add to a combat scene costs some points from the NPC budget. Most NPCs cost 1 point to add to a scene, but NPCs with certain templates, like Minions or Mini-Bosses, cost different amounts.

    NPC BUDGET COSTS NPC BUDGET COSTS
    1 Minion NPC 0.25 points
    4 Minion NPCs 1 point
    1 NPC 1 point
    1 Veteran NPC 1.5 points
    1 Elite NPC 2 points
    1 Mini-Boss NPC 3 points

    If an NPC has multiple templates with different costs (e.g., an Elite Veteran), just take the highest cost.

    Using fewer NPCs than your NPC budget allows for will result in easier combat scenes, while going over your budget will result in harder combat scenes.

    Other factors can also change the difficulty of a combat scene:

    • If there are more PCs than there are NPCs, the PCs have a huge advantage because of the number of turns available to them versus the NPCs. Try to design combat scenes so there aren't many more PCs than NPCs.
    • Minions are easily defeated, but do just as much damage as standard NPCs. Too many Minions can quickly overwhelm the PCs.
    • Mini-Bosses shouldn't fight the PCs alone. Any single character, even a Mini-Boss, is quickly overwhelmed by multiple opponents.

    Ultimately, figuring out what counts as an easy, normal, or hard combat scene is more art than science because there are just so many variables. A combat scene that seems hard on paper might be very easy for your players because their builds counter the NPCs you picked. The more you play with your group and the more familiar you become with their characters, the more accurately you'll be able to achieve your intended difficulty.

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    MAPMAKING

    Combat scenes take place on a battle map , a special type of gridded map that traditionally uses square or hex spaces. You can use either type of spaces for BEACON , since the game is measured in spaces of any type. 1 space can be either 1 square or 1 hex.

    This section provides guidance on how to make a fun battle map, from choosing the correct size to populating it with interesting features.

    Map Size

    The size of the map often varies from scene to scene:

    • Smaller maps usually have a longest side of approximately 20 spaces.
    • Standard-sized maps have a longest side of approximately 25 spaces
    • Larger maps usually have a longest side of approximately 40 spaces.

    Battle plans other than Elimination assume a map with a longest side of 40 spaces or less. They can be used with smaller or larger maps, but certain battle plans might be easier or harder with different map sizes.

    Map Features

    Combat scenes should take place in interesting places with interesting features, not small, featureless rooms.

    Here are some tips for building interesting combat scenes:

    • Add sections of soft and/or hard cover. Tables, trees, walls, and other elements can all be cover.
    • Add obstacles or large pieces of terrain to block line of sight.
    • Add places on the map that beacons can get bonuses for reaching - regaining RECOVERIES , HP , or MP ; getting a reroll on the next loot crate; and so on.
    • Spice things up with environmental factors and terrain features.
    • Create zones that provide tactical options for players. Getting from point A to point B might involve crossing an open field and being vulnerable to a Sharpshooter NPC. Consider adding an alternative route that is longer but protected from enemy fire.
    • Mix up the size and width of pathways.

    BATTLE PLAN

    Each combat scene has a battle plan . Battle plans provide the framework for combat scenes, determining the win conditions for the PCs, the NPC budget, and any special rules. These are designed to make combat scenes more engaging than just 'destroy all enemies' . Many battle plans feature solutions that allow scenes to be resolved quickly.

    In the absence of another battle plan, combat scenes default to Elimination (see below).

    Terminology

    • Control Zone: Certain battle plans feature control zones, which are areas on the battlefield that PCs and NPCs must fight over.
    • Deployment Zone: In scenes that have them, PCs and NPCs start within their respective deployment zones. Not every battle plan has deployment zones.
    • Escape Zone: PCs can use escape zones to leave a combat scene. Battle plans that feature escape zones explain how they're used.
    • Reinforcements: Reinforcements are characters that join a combat scene after the first round.
    • Reinforcement Zone: NPC reinforcements enter the combat scene within reinforcement zones.
    • Objectives: Objectives are characters, objects, or zones that the PCs must interact with in certain ways. Objectives don't take turns. They automatically fail all checks or saves, and clear all conditions, effects, and statuses at the start of each round.

    Elements

    Every battle plan contains the following elements, which shape how the combat scene plays out.

    • Map: Every battle plan contains an example map. This map is meant to represent how the combat scene should be laid out and can be used as a starting point when creating an actual battle map.
    • Goal: The goal is whatever the PCs must do to achieve victory in the combat scene. Some battle plans have secondary goals, which must be completed after the primary goal to secure victory.
    • Setup: The setup provides recommendations on how the combat scene should be laid out.
    • Rules: Some battle plans have special rules. This section explains how they work.
    • NPC Prep: This describes how many NPCs the GM should prepare and whether or not there are reinforcements. In addition, it indicates whether the PCs or NPCs deploy first in the combat scene. Whichever side deploys first must decide where in their deployment zones they want to start without knowing the locations of their opponents.
    • Reinforcements: This outlines when enemy reinforcements join the combat scene, and where from.

    Acqusition

    The beacons have to fight through enemies toward a location, and then keep their foes out. These combat scenes often involve securing a person or location held by enemy forces.

    Goal: Have more PCs than enemy NPCs in the control zone at the end of Round 6.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map. Place a control zone near the opposite side of the map. This control zone is also the NPC deployment zone. It should be fortified with cover and large enough for multiple characters to occupy at the same time. Place reinforcement zones along the edges of the map.

    Rules: At the end of Round 6, determine if there are more enemy NPCs in the control zone than PCs. Mini-Bosses count as 4 characters each, Elites count as 2, Minions count as 1/4, and Summons count as 0.

    NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget, but half are reinforcements . NPCs deploy first.

    Reinforcements: At the end of Round 1, the GM deploys all reinforcements in any reinforcement zones.

    Assassination

    An important target has been identified and must be eliminated. Once this is done, the beacons have to safely escape.

    Goal: Defeat the objective by the end of Round 8.

    Secondary Goal: Defeat all enemy NPCs or escape.

    Setup: Enemy NPCs can deploy anywhere on the map. Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map and place the objective anywhere on the map, ideally far from the PC deployment zone. Next, place an escape zone somewhere on the map, typically between the PC deployment zone and the objective. Reinforcement zones are located throughout the map, either along the edge or at locations where allies of the objective can appear, like houses or barracks.

    Rules: The objective is a Veteran or Elite NPC. They should not be a Mini-Boss. When acting, they prioritize survival. Only the PCs can escape. They can do so as a free action at the end of their turn while partly inside the escape zone. After defeating the objective, the combat scene only ends when either:

    • all enemy NPCs are defeated
    • all undefeated PCs escape
    • all PCs are defeated.

    NPC Prep: 2.5 x NPC budget, but half are reinforcements . NPCs deploy first.

    Reinforcements: At the start of any round before the target is defeated, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or up to two other NPCs in any reinforcement zones. Once the target is defeated, no more reinforcements appear.

    BuildinG BeaconS

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    Control

    The beacons must hold locations of strategic importance like mines, food stores, or barracks.

    Goal: Have more points than the NPCs at the end of Round 5.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone and an NPC deployment zone along opposite edges of the map. The NPC deployment zone should be larger than the PC deployment zone and is also a reinforcement zone. Place four control zones, evenly spaced between the PC and NPC deployment zones.

    Rules: At the end of each round, determine if either side controls any control zones. Control zones are controlled if one side has more characters in the zone than the other side, excluding Summons . Each side gets 1 point for every zone it controls. If either side controls all four zones, it gains +1 point.

    At the end of Round 6, the team with the most points wins.

    NPC Prep: 2 x NPC budget, but half are reinforcements . Roll a d6. On a 1-3, the NPCs deploy first.

    Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or up to two other NPCs in any reinforcement zones.

    Defense

    The beacons must protect someone or something from hostile forces that want them (or it) dead.

    Goal: Protect the objective until the end of Round 5. If the objective is defeated or destroyed, the PCs automatically lose.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone near the center of the map, fortified with cover. Additionally, place an NPC deployment zone around the edge of the map. This is also a reinforcement zone.

    Place the objective inside the PC deployment zone.

    Rules: The objective is a character or object with the following attributes:

    SIZE 1/2 to 2 , HP 25/30/35 , DODGE / A-DEF 10

    The enemy NPCs should focus on attacking the objective. If the objective is a character or object that can be moved, then when a character begins their standard movement adjacent to it, the objective moves along with that character. At the end of that movement, the player can place the objective in any adjacent free space. If the objective is adjacent to two characters from different sides, it stops moving and won't move further. The objective doesn't move on its own.

    NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

    Reinforcements: If any NPCs are held as reinforcements, they can be deployed in reinforcement zones at the start of any round.

    Destruction

    The beacons have a brief opportunity to destroy a number of objectives before time runs out.

    Goal: Destroy all objectives before the end of Round 8. If any objectives remain at this time, the PCs automatically lose.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map. Then, place an NPC deployment zone near the opposite end of the map and reinforcement zones along the other edges of the map.

    Scatter 1-5 objectives around the map, gravitating toward the NPC deployment zone.

    Rules: The objectives are objects with the following attributes:

    SIZE 1 to 2 , HP = see below, DODGE / A-DEF 5

    To calculate the objectives' HP , multiply the number of PCs by 20 and divide this number evenly between the objectives. For example, with four PCs, the pool of HP is 80 . With two objectives, each has 40 HP . With four objectives, each has 20 HP .

    The objectives do not clear Discord and they take any ongoing Discord damage at the end of each round.

    NPC Prep: Slightly more than the normal NPC budget, but not more than twice the budget. NPCs over the normal budget are held as reinforcements . Enemy NPCs deploy first.

    Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or up to two other NPCs in any reinforcement zones.

    Elimination

    Two or more sides must fight until their enemies are defeated or in rout.

    Goal: Defeat all enemies.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone and, if there are reinforcements, reinforcement zones anywhere on the map. NPCs can be deployed anywhere.

    Rules: No special rules.

    NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget. Roll a d6. On a 1-3, the NPCs deploy first. If the PCs deploy first, don't surround them with NPCs - place them in interesting places, instead.

    Reinforcements: If any NPCs are held as reinforcements, any number of them can be deployed in reinforcement zones at the start of a round.

    Escort

    The beacons seek to escort someone through enemy lines. The enemy forces want this person for themselves, and will try to take them or prevent the beacons from moving them.

    Goal: Escape with the objective before the end of Round 8.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map and an escape zone on the opposite edge. Next, place an NPC deployment zone between the PC deployment zone and the escape zone, and reinforcement zones along the other edges of the map.

    Rules: The objective is a character with these attributes:

    SIZE 1/2 to 2 , HP = 10 SIZE (MIN 10), DODGE / A-DEF 10

    Enemy NPCs should not willingly attack or damage the objective.

    When a character begins their standard movement adjacent to the objective, the objective moves along with them. At the end of that movement, the player can place the objective in any adjacent free space. If the objective is adjacent to two characters from different sides, the objective stops moving, won't move further, and they are considered contested . The objective doesn't move on their own.

    Only PCs can escape. They can do so as a free action at the end of their turn while partly within the escape zone. The objective escapes if they are adjacent to a PC that escapes and aren't contested.

    NPC Prep: 2 NPC budget, but half are held as reinforcements . NPCs deploy after the PCs. The PCs deploy the objective in their deployment zone when they deploy.

    Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or one other NPC in any reinforcement zone.

    Holdout

    The beacons need to hold the line against unending waves of enemies, preventing their foes from overwhelming the space they control.

    Goal: At the end of Round 6, there are fewer enemy NPCs (excluding Summons ) in the control zone than there were PCs at the beginning of the combat scene.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone near the center of the map. This is also the control zone and should be fortified with cover. The edges of the map are both the NPC deployment zone and the reinforcement zone.

    Rules: Defeated NPC units (excluding Mini-Bosses) return as reinforcements after a number of rounds equal their WOUND CAP .

    NPC Prep: 3 + NPC budget. NPCs beyond the budget are held as reinforcements. NPCs deploy after PCs.

    Reinforcements: At the start of each round after the first, the GM can deploy all reinforcements in the reinforcement zone.

    Raid

    In a raid, the beacons rush to collect something, whether it be strategic resources or vital information.

    Goal: End Round 4, 5, or 6 with X treasure, where X = the number of PCs +1.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone and an NPC deployment zone on opposite edges of the map, and 1-4 reinforcement zones along the other edges. Distribute chests equal to twice the number of PCs around the map.

    Rules: While in the space of a chest, PCs can open it as a minor action . Some chests might be locked. When a PC opens a chest, they gain 1 treasure.

    Characters can hold any amount of treasure at once. Whenever a character holding treasure takes a Wound or Overstress, they drop all their treasure in an adjacent space of their choice. They can also willingly drop all their treasure as a minor action . Characters can pick up all treasure in a space they occupy as a minor action .

    Enemy NPCs don't open chests, but will pick up dropped treasure.

    NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

    Reinforcements: If any NPCs are held as reinforcements, any number of them can be deployed in reinforcement zones at the start of a round.

    Rescue

    The beacons must fight their way to someone in need of rescue and safely escape with them.

    Goal: Escape with the objective before the end of Round 10.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map. This is also the escape zone. Next, place an NPC deployment zone on the opposite side of the map, surrounded by cover and fortifications. Place reinforcement zones along the other edges of the map and the objective in the NPC deployment zone.

    Rules: The objective is a character with these attributes:

    SIZE 1/2 to 2 , HP = 10 SIZE (MIN 10), DODGE / A-DEF 10

    Enemy NPCs will not willingly attack or damage the objective.

    When a character begins their standard movement adjacent to the objective, the objective moves along with them. At the end of that movement, the player can place the objective in any adjacent free space. If the objective is adjacent to two characters from different sides, the objective stops moving, won't move further, and they are considered contested . The objective doesn't move on their own.

    Only the PCs can escape. They can do so as a free action at the end of their turn while partly inside the escape zone. The objective escapes if they are adjacent to a PC that escapes and aren't contested.

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    NPC Prep: 2 NPC budget, but most are held as reinforcements. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

    Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions between two reinforcement zones or two other NPCs in different reinforcement zones. A used reinforcement zone can't be used for reinforcements in the next round.

    Search

    There is something hidden in one four places. The beacons must find it and control it before it's too late.

    Goal: Control the objective at the end of Round 6.

    Setup: Place an NPC deployment zone in the middle of the map. Next, place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map and the reinforcement zone along the opposite edge. Lastly, place four control zones, one of which is secretly the objective .

    Rules: Within a control zone, PCs can use their standard action during any phase to learn whether it is the objective or not. They can't do this if there are any NPCs in the control zone.

    NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

    Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or one other NPC in the reinforcement zone.

    Survival

    In desperate times, survival is everything. Hide, fight, run away - all that matters is that you survive.

    Goal: At least half of the PCs (rounded up) must be undefeated or all NPCs and reinforcements must be defeated by the end of Round 5.

    Setup: Place a PC deployment zone near the center of the map, surrounded by cover and fortifications. The NPC deployment zone and reinforcement zone runs along the outer edge of the map.

    Rules: No special rules.

    NPC Prep: 2 NPC budget, but half are held as reinforcements. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

    Reinforcements: At the start of Round 3, deploy all reinforcements in the reinforcement zone.

    ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS AND TERRAIN FEATURES

    An interesting environment is a key part of a memorable combat scene. This section outlines a range of environmental factors and terrain features you can use in combat scenes, including the basic ones discussed earlier in the book.

    Environmental Factors

    Environmental factors are effects that alter combat scenes, individual spaces, or even objects. Some apply to the entire combat scene, while others affect characters in smaller areas, such as in the case of a room with poor visibility.

    COLD

    When characters within this environment take Stress from other characters, they take -1 Stress . When they take Lunar from other characters, they take +1 Lunar .

    HEAT

    When characters within this environment take Stress from other characters, they take an additional +1 Stress . When they take Astral from other characters, they take +1 Astral .

    HIGH WINDS

    At the start of each round, the GM chooses one side of the map. The winds are blowing in this direction. At the start of each character's turn while within this environment, they are pushed 1 space in the indicated direction, or 1d6 spaces if they are FLYING .

    LOCKS

    Doors, gates, and treasure chests can all be locked, preventing them from being opened. A locked entrance - a bolted door, for instance - can't be moved through. The contents of chests and other objects that are locked can't be accessed.

    To unlock something, you can make an AGILITY check as part of the action to interact with it. On a success, the lock is disabled and the object is opened.

    LOW GRAVITY

    Characters in low-gravity environments can jump further than normal. When they begin their standard movement or begin a RUSH movement while within this environment, they can choose to gain FLYING , and can move up to half their SPEED in a straight line in addition to that movement. They lose FLYING at the end of that movement.

    LOW VISIBILITY

    Low visibility can represent darkness, fog, and other effects that make it hard to see. It affects how far characters can see, and makes it harder to find HIDDEN characters. Low visibility has the following effects:

    • Characters are INVISIBLE while HIDDEN .
    • SCOPE and the RANGE of all weapons are reduced by half. REACH and AOEs are not affected.

    MANA VORTEXES

    Mana vortexes alter the cost of spells, making them more or less expensive. There are two types of mana zones:

    • Mana Field: Mana fields reduce the MP cost of all spells used within them by -1, to a minimum of 0.
    • Mana Void: Mana voids increase the MP cost of all spells used within them by +1. This even applies to spells that don't usually have a MP cost.

    POISONOUS

    Characters must succeed on a BULK check at the start of each of their turns while within this environment or take 1 DISCORD .

    UNDERWATER/ZERO-GRAVITY

    Combat scenes that take place completely underwater or in zero-gravity treat all characters as FLYING . However, unless they have flight or an Aquatic Adaptation (granted by certain abilities), they can't RUSH or shift .

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    Terrain Features

    Terrain features modify spaces and terrain on the battlefield. They are not objects unless specifically indicated otherwise. While they generally affect single spaces, multiple terrain features can be placed next to each other to create a continuous feature. For example, you can have a single space of lava as dangerous terrain, but you could also connect multiple lava spaces to create a lava flow, all of which count as the same piece of dangerous terrain.

    ARMOR RACK

    Characters can use an adjacent armor rack as a minor action , gaining one of the following effects for the rest of the scene:

    • They gain +2 ARMOR .
    • They gain resistance to either Physical, Force, Astral, or Lunar .

    By default, each armor rack can be used once per scene.

    BALLISTA

    While characters are within a ballista's space, their ranged weapons gain +5 RANGE .

    BLESSED TERRAIN

    Characters in blessed terrain gain +1 on attacks, checks, and saves.

    CATAPULT

    While characters are within a catapult's space, their ranged and thrown weapon attacks gain Arcing .

    CHARGED TERRAIN

    Characters that end their turn in charged terrain take 5 PIERCING ASTRAL , -1 for every space they moved that turn.

    CHASM

    Chasms have no ground beneath them, or ground so far away that characters entering them must expend great effort to return.

    NonFLYING characters that fully enter a chasm immediately stop moving, take 2 STRESS , and end their turn if it was their turn. Characters that start their turn in a chasm can immediately use their standard movement to move to the nearest free non-chasm space. Otherwise, they suffer the effects of the chasm.

    COVER

    See p. 50 for detailed information on cover.

    CREEPING TERRAIN

    Any other type of terrain can be creeping terrain, allowing it to move at the start of each round. The GM determines how far creeping terrain can move, but 2-3 spaces is a good baseline.

    CURSED TERRAIN

    Characters in cursed terrain receive +1 on attacks, checks, and saves.

    DAWN STONE

    Dawn stones are immovable objects with DODGE 5 and 1 HP . They don't cause obstruction and are auto-hit by AOE effects.

    Dawn stones emit BURST 2 zones around themselves that negate the effects of low visibility. If a dawn stone is destroyed, characters within the zone must succeed on a BULK check or be BLINDED until cleared.

    DIFFICULT AND DANGEROUS TERRAIN

    Difficult terrain is anything that slows movement, like mud, water, or thick grass. Difficult terrain has +1 movement cost.

    Dangerous terrain is any type of terrain that can cause damage, like lava or thorns.

    1/round , when you enter dangerous terrain or end your turn in it, you must make an ability check of the GM's choice. On a failure, you take 5 damage of any type or Stress based on the type of terrain.

    DUSK STONE

    Dusk stones are immovable objects with DODGE 5 and 1 HP . They don't cause obstruction and are auto-hit by AOE effects.

    Dusk stones emit BURST 2 zones around themselves that cause low visibility. If a dusk stone is destroyed, characters within the zone are INVISIBLE until the end of their next turn.

    EMPTY SPACE/FREE SPACE

    A free space is a space that doesn't contain any characters or objects. Empty spaces, on the other hand, are more specific than free spaces. Empty spaces are those that don't contain any characters, objects, terrain, or terrain features.

    Some abilities affect free spaces, while others will affect empty spaces only.

    ETHEREAL RIFT

    Characters that enter an ethereal rift can move through obstructions and ignore ENGAGEMENT until the end of their next turn, but can't end their turn inside an obstruction.

    EXPLOSIVE ZONE

    Explosive zones increase the size of AOEs. If an AOE would include any spaces of an explosive zone, the AOE's size is increased by +1. A LINE 10 AOE becomes LINE 11 , a CLOSE BLAST 2 AOE becomes CLOSE BLAST 3 , and so on.

    FLAMMABLE TERRAIN

    When a character standing in flammable terrain takes Astral or an AOE that deals Astral hits a space of flammable terrain, the terrain ignites (along with any adjacent flammable terrain). Characters in connected spaces (including diagonally) of flammable terrain must make an AGILITY check. Failure: They take 5 DISCORD . Success: They take 3 DISCORD . Either way, the spaces then become dangerous terrain ( AGILITY , 5 ASTRAL ) until the end of the scene.

    FOCUS ZONE

    Characters that start their turn in a focus zone take 3/4/5 STRESS if they don't use a spell that turn.

    FOG

    Fog provides soft cover to characters fully within it.

    FRICTIONLESS TERRAIN

    Characters that enter frictionless terrain or move while within it continue moving in a straight line until they hit an obstruction or character, or move out of the frictionless terrain. This is considered forced movement.

    FURY ZONE

    Characters that start their turn in a fury zone take 3/4/5 STRESS if they don't attack with a weapon that turn.

    GROWING TERRAIN

    Any other type of terrain can be growing terrain, causing it to grow by 1d3 spaces at the start of each round.

    HARPOON

    Characters standing in a harpoon's space can use their standard action during any phase to make a ranged weapon attack against a target within RANGE 15 .

    On Hit: The target takes 1D6+1 PIERCING PHYSICAL , loses FLYING , and cannot resume FLYING until this phase in the next round.

    Harpoons must be reloaded after each use. They can be reloaded with a standard action during any phase, or are automatically reloaded if a character in its space reloads a weapon.

    HEALING FONT

    Characters adjacent to a healing font can regain all HP as a minor action . Once used in this way, the healing font is expended.

    HIGH GROUND

    High ground provides benefits that represent being at a higher elevation than other characters, similar to those received when FLYING . Characters standing on high ground gain the following benefits:

    • Non-thrown melee attacks against them from nonFLYING characters that aren't on high ground receive +2 .
    • They neither become ENGAGED by nor cause ENGAGEMENT to nonFLYING characters that aren't on high ground.
    • Their attacks gain +1 against nonFLYING character that aren't on high ground.
