    Accessing high ground sometimes requires special movement, like flying or climbing.

    HOLY GROUND

    When characters in holy ground would regain HP, they regain twice as much HP instead. This does not apply to characters with the Undead or Vampiric templates.

    IMPASSABLE TERRAIN

    Impassable terrain is any terrain, like a wall or a cliff, that cannot normally be traversed except by characters who possess a type of movement that allows them to do so, like flying or climbing. Some impassable terrain cannot be entered at all (e.g., a pillar that reaches up to the ceiling or the walls of an underground dungeon).

    MANA FONT

    Characters adjacent to a mana font can regain all MP as a minor action . Once used in this way, the mana font is expended.

    MONSTER SPAWNER

    Monster spawners are objects that continually summon NPC reinforcements at the start of each round until disabled. These reinforcements are not considered part of the NPC budget. Monster spawners can be disabled with a successful ability check of the GM's choice as a minor action .

    By default, monster spawners can't be attacked or destroyed. At the GM's option, a spawner may have 10/15/20 HP and DODGE 6.

    GettinG Started

    BuildinG BeaconS

    runninG tHe Game

    10: Game maSter'S Guide aPPendiceS

    NOXIOUS FUMES

    Noxious fumes provide soft cover . Characters that start their turn in noxious fumes must succeed on a BULK check or take 1 DISCORD , or if they already have Discord , take Discord equal to their current Discord .

    Pits are difficult-to-escape holes in the ground. Characters fully inside a pit can only move to adjacent pit spaces unless they are FLYING or can teleport . Characters within a pit can use their standard movement or RUSH to move to an adjacent non-pit space.

    SLIPPERY TERRAIN

    Slippery terrain is difficult terrain . Characters that start their turn in slippery terrain must succeed on an AGILITY check or fall PRONE . Characters that ignore difficult terrain ignore this effect.

    STICKY TERRAIN

    Sticky terrain is difficult terrain . Characters that start their turn in sticky terrain must succeed on a BULK check or be IMMOBILIZED .

    TELEPORT PAD

    Teleport pads can be one-way or two-way:

    • One-Way: There are three types of one-way teleport pads, which determine their effects. When a character enters the teleport pad's space, they experience the relevant effect:
    • They teleport to a specific space.
    • They teleport 1d6 spaces in a random direction.
    • They teleport 1d6 spaces in a specific direction.
    • Two-Way: Each two-way teleport pad is connected to another. When a character enters the teleport pad's space, they are teleported to the connected pad. If the other teleport pad is occupied, the teleport fails.

    TRAPS

    Traps are interactable objects with the Trap tag (p. 65). While many Traps are PC or NPC abilities, you can use the following Traps to represent Traps already on the battlefield.

    Condition: The triggering character gains a condition based on the type of Trap . IMMOBILIZED , SLOWED , and BLINDED are common.

    Condition, Area: When triggered, all characters in a BURST 1 AOE must make a save of the GM's choice. Failure: They gain a condition, chosen when the Trap is set.

    Damage: The triggering character takes 6/8/10 damage of any type, chosen when the Trap is set.

    Damage, Area: When triggered, all characters in a BURST 1 AOE must make save of the GM's choice. Failure: The target takes 6/8/10 damage of any type, chosen when the Trap is set. Success: They take 3/4/5 damage instead.

    TREASURE CHEST

    Treasure chests are objects that don't cause obstruction and that contain bonus effects for the players, chosen from the table below. Players always know the contents of chests. The GM can decide if the bonuses apply to the character that opened the chest or everyone on their team. Some bonuses provide immediate effects, while others provide delayed effects or permanent resources.

    Chests can be accessed with a minor action while in their space, but might be locked (see the locked environmental feature).

    SAMPLE CHEST REWARDS

    • 1 A reroll on the next loot crate's first slot. Subsequent instances of this bonus increase the slot that can be rerolled. For example, getting this reward twice means that you can reroll either the first or second slot.

    2

    +X

    GOLD

    • 3 +X RECOVERIES
    • 4 Repair a destroyed weapon, support item, or technique for free
    • 5 A specific piece of loot

    6 Regain X uses of a Consumable ability

    • 7 Increase current and total MP by X for the rest of the scene

    8

    Stress

    Clear all

    UNHOLY GROUND

    When characters in unholy ground would regain HP , they regain half the HP instead. This does not apply to characters with the Undead or Vampiric templates.

    UPDRAFT

    Characters in an updraft gain FLYING for as long as they are in an updraft, or until the end of their turn if they leave an updraft.

    WEAPON RACK

    Characters can use an adjacent weapon rack as a minor action , choosing one of the following options:

    • They repair a destroyed weapon for free.
    • They gain +1 on all attacks with a weapon of their choice for the rest of the scene.

    By default, each weapon rack can be used once per scene.

    INFORMATION TRANSPARENCY

    Combat in BEACON is based around information transparency. Your goal as GM isn't to hide information from your players or trick them, but instead to allow them to make informed decisions.

    During combat scenes, you should always share the following information with players:

    • The NPC types and templates for all enemies.
    • The locations of enemies on the map at all times, regardless of line of sight or whether they are HIDDEN or INVISIBLE .
    • The conditions and statuses of all enemies.
    • The battle plan and all relevant goals.
    • The locations of all Traps .
    • The mechanics of any abilities or items that NPCs use.

    Other information is restricted unless a beacon has a specific way to access it. This includes the ability scores and attributes of NPCs and the specific features they have equipped. Certain abilities, like the LORE BOOK support item (p. 218), can provide access to restricted information.

    COMBAT SCENE TIPS

    Combat scenes have a lot of moving parts. These including creating a fair, balanced, and interesting fight for the players; designing the battle map; and controlling the NPCs during the fight.

    This section contains some general, helpful tips to keep in mind when creating combat scenes.

    MAKE THEM INTERESTING

    Combat scenes should be more than just generic battles against faceless minions. There should be stakes, reasons for fighting, and environmental features that make them interesting.

    An example of a boring combat scene would be a simple dungeon room with a bunch of animated skeletons guarding the exit. A more exciting example would have the beacons finding an underground mausoleum, in which a royal animated skeleton sits atop a bone throne and attacks anyone who enters with an endlessly spawning army of lesser skeletons. These foes can only be stopped if the beacons destroy their sarcophagi.

    KEEP PLAYERS ACTIVE

    Depending on the actions players take each round, there can be a decent amount of time between their turns. Try to minimize situations that would take players out of a fight. Fill combat scenes with different things people can interact with so they have things to do other than just attacking enemies. Environmental factors, terrain features like high ground , and civilians in need of rescue are all examples of things between which players might need to split their focus.

    PLAY TO YOUR PLAYERS' STRENGTHS

    There are a wide variety of NPC types that you can use, and some of them are strong against specific play styles.

    When designing combat scenes, make sure to play to the strengths of the PCs, not their weaknesses. Use NPCs that counter PCs as a way to challenge them, not as a way to beat them. As a player, it always feels better to defeat an NPC than to feel like you aren't contributing anything.

    CHOOSE THE RIGHT SIZE AND TERRAIN

    Every combat scene takes place on a battle map. The size of these maps may vary from scene to scene, but on average, they should be around 25 spaces by 25 spaces. This gives enough room for tight, efficient scenes.

    Avoid combats in plain, open fields. Placing terrain and objects around the battlefield gives people opportunities to find cover and avoid line of sight.

    BuildinG BeaconS

    PLAY SMART

    You don't need to alter your tactics based on the intelligence of your NPCs. You're encouraged to act intelligently, attacking vulnerable characters and avoiding dangerous situations.

    For example, beacons have the ability to actively defend each other using INTERPOSE or other defensive abilities. You can intentionally attack beacons supporting their allies from the back lines, because defender-type beacons will be able to step in and protect them. Unlike other games, you don't need to directly target the defender-type beacons just because they're the 'party tank' . Attack intelligently, and let your players utilize their defensive abilities.

    That being said, you don't HAVE to do this. You can intentionally have your NPCs use poor tactics or make bad decisions. For example, you can play an NPC Fury as someone that only attacks the closest enemy. Just know that the game is designed around the idea that you can attack intelligently as a GM and don't need to pull your punches.

    But remember: always root for your players to win.

    USE A VARIETY OF NPC ROLES

    Each NPC type has a role, much like classes do: defender, striker, controller, and so on.

    When designing combat scenes, it's best to use a variety of NPC types. This makes the combat feel more dynamic and gives the PCs more engaging decisions points. For example, if there's a Healer NPC keeping a Protector NPC alive, it will encourage the PCs to find a way to take out the Healer first.

    Above all, don't put too many defenders in a combat scene. Defenders generally have high HP and low damage output, so combat scenes filled with too many of them can feel like a slog.

    USE NPCS WITH VARYING INITIATIVES

    NPCs have set INITIATIVE scores (p. 260) and act in specific phases instead of operating according to the freeform approach used by PCs. Try to incorporate NPCs with a variety of INITIATIVE scores into each combat scene, keeping them from all clumping together.

    For example, the Architect, Gladiator, and Firebug NPC types all have INITIATIVE 5 . If you have them all in a combat scene, that will slow everything down during PHASE . One result is that the PCs won't have much reason to change their plans on the fly, since they know the NPCs will always act during PHASE . Instead, consider using a Protector ( INITIATIVE 1 ), Firebug ( INITIATIVE 5 ), and Titan ( INITIATIVE 7 ). These NPC types have the same roles, but their actions are spread out through the phases.

    LOOT AND REWARDS

    Beacons can receive additional rewards outside of their class-based rewards. These rewards might be primarily narrative, like gaining the trust or backing of a powerful organization, while others have effects in combat play, like SUPPLIES , RESIDUUM , and loot .

    Loot is the most common type of reward that beacons will acquire during the game, as they'll earn at least one piece of loot after every quest.

    LOOT

    Loot includes a range of equipment and techniques that aren't tied to specific classes. It is usually presented to the players via loot crates . A loot crate is a set of three random pieces of loot from which the player can select one to keep. The full list of loot can be found in Appendix B: Loot (p. 356).

    Once a beacon has obtained a particular piece of loot, it operates like any other unlockable equipment or technique. They have permanent access to it and can choose to equip it when preparing for quests. Unless it is Unique , they can equip multiple instances of it at a time.

    Loot is categorized by rarity. It can be Uncommon , Rare , or Legendary . The rarer a piece of loot, the more likely it is to have powerful effects. That doesn't mean more common items are weak, however; the power of loot is very dependent on the play style of the beacon that uses it.

    Here's an example of a piece of loot:

    On Crit: You regain 1 MP and your target loses 1 MP .

    As you can see, ABSORPTION looks just like any other weapon. The only difference is the rarity tag, which is Uncommon in this case.

    Assigning Loot

    After every quest, each player receives a loot crate whether or not the quest was successful.

    Each player's loot crate is unique, and whatever they choose from it is tied to their character specifically. By default, players can't trade loot between each other.

    Bonus Loot

    Whenever you feel appropriate, you can give out extra loot crates or even give players specific pieces of loot.

    In the case of a narratively unique piece of loot, like a TENTACLE ROD crafted from the severed arm of a Kraken

    Boss the beacons defeated, you might offer one copy to the group as a whole and let the players decide who gets to keep it. For pieces of loot that are less unique, you can give a copy to each player.

    Loot Crates

    Each loot crate has three slots, each containing a random piece of loot. The contents of the slots are generated using either an online generator or by rolling a percentile die (d100).

    Slots 1, 2, and 3 each have their own rarity scale, with Slots 2 and 3 being more likely to contain rarer loot.

    The chances of a slot holding a weapon, support item, or technique are almost identical. Because it isn't possible to divide 100 by three with dice, however, techniques are very slightly more common.

    Creating Loot Crates

    You can use this online GM sheet to easily generate loot crates. To manually create a loot crate, use the following steps for each slot, consulting the table below:

    • 1 Determine type: Roll a d100 to determine if the slot contains a weapon, support item, or technique.
    • 2 Determine rarity: Roll a d100 to determine the rarity of the slot's contents.
    • 3 Determine loot: Choose a piece of loot that matches the type and rarity results for that slot. You can either hand-pick loot or use a random number generator to generate a result using the tables in Appendix B: Loot (Type and Rarity, p. 383).
    LOOT CRATE CONTENTS LOOT CRATE CONTENTS LOOT CRATE CONTENTS LOOT CRATE CONTENTS
    D100 TYPE (ANY SLOT)
    1-17 SKILL SKILL SKILL
    18-34 SPELL SPELL SPELL
    35-67 WEAPON WEAPON WEAPON
    68-100 SUPPORTITEM SUPPORTITEM SUPPORTITEM
    RARITY SLOT 1 D100 SLOT 2 SLOT 3
    Uncommon 1-75 1-30 -
    Rare 76-100 31-90 1-75
    Legendary - 91-100 76-100

    TRADING LOOT

    By default, loot can't be traded between players. This is to prevent players from funneling all of their loot to one person, or feeling entitled to a piece of loot someone else has that would be perfect for their own character. In short, it's a limitation meant to protect everyone's play experience.

    One of the most common house rules for BEACON is allowing beacons to trade loot between each other. If you know your group and they work well together, feel free to use that approach.

    Residuum

    Residuum can be spent to reroll the random options found in loot crates. Residuum is created with the DISENCHANT LOOT downtime activity and can be spent to apply the following effects. You can choose more than one option to apply to a single roll, and can choose the same option multiple times:

    • 1 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot.
    • 2 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot and choose a specific type for the slot (weapon, support item, skill, or spell).
    • 2 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot. The rerolled slot will be one level rarer than the original result (Uncommon > Rare > Legendary).

    Loot is meant to be a fun, random way of getting additional equipment and techniques beyond the ones granted by classes.

    In other games that use loot as a reward, it is usually based on the GMs discretion. BEACON puts that part of the game back into the players' hands. They will always get a piece of loot, and will get to make a choice about it, even though it may not be useful to their particular build.

    There are downtime activities, like SHOP , that let players trade in loot that they don't plan on using.

    OTHER REWARDS

    The players can obtain other rewards that don't have direct rules effects through narrative play. These might include the backing of a powerful organization, an airship, or another base of operations. While these rewards shape the story, they don't have direct effects on combat.

    BuildinG BeaconS

    HOMEBREW RULES

    'Homebrew' is when you design your own gameplay elements for an existing game - like creating your own classes or equipment for BEACON !

    I love homebrew, and a lot of people enjoy adding to existing games. Heck, BEACON originally started as a homebrew version of Lancer!

    I encourage you to make homebrew if you're interested. Things that are especially easy to customize or create include NPC types and loot. It can be trickier to create new classes or talents because they have the potential to interact with all other aspects of the game.

    Creating variant jobs is a simpler option than creating whole new classes. Variant jobs are variations of the existing jobs that players get through classes. Each class has a job of the same name. For example, the Warlord class has the Warlord job by default; however, if you designed a Valkyrie job, you could make that a variant Warlord job. When one of your players gains rank 1 in the Warlord class, they could choose to gain either the Warlord job or the Valkyrie job (but not both).

    There's also room for prestige jobs . These jobs aren't tied to specific classes, but can instead be unlocked through downtime activities. This is a great way to add homebrew jobs to the game, and you can easily introduce a trainer or downtime activity to provide players with access to it.

    11: NON-PLAYER CHARACTERS

    Characters controlled by the GM are called non-player characters , or NPCs. NPCs can be friends, foes, beasts, or anything else that the GM presents.

    In narrative play, NPCs don't roll dice or have attributes. Instead, they react to actions taken by the players.

    In combat play, NPCs are characters with their own set of rules that are slightly different from the players. Bosses are a special type of NPC, meant to challenge an entire group of beacons by themselves, and have their own unique rules (see p. 323).

    This chapter covers the rules that govern NPCs, as well as the specific types of NPCs that can be used in combat scenes.

    COMBAT PLAY NPCS

    BEACON doesn't give unique attributes for every single character and monster the players might face. Instead, each NPC fits into one of several broad frameworks, called NPC types .

    NPCs can be further customized with templates. Instead of having character levels like beacons, they have a tier from 1-3.

    ALLIED NPCS

    Occasionally, an NPC will fight on the side of the beacons. These allied NPCs are still considered NPCs and controlled by the GM, but are allies of the PCs and enemies of the opposing NPCs.

    NPC TYPE

    NPC types are collections of abilities and attributes that represent general themes, similar to beacons' jobs. For example, an NPC with the Firebug type could be a fire-breathing dragon as easily as it could be a magitech pyromancer.

    An NPC's type determines the ability scores, attributes, and abilities that the NPC will use. NPCs' ability scores and attributes are static numbers and aren't calculated like they are for beacons, although they can increase at higher tiers.

    For example, the Cleaver NPC type has 2 BULK and 16 HP at tier 1. At tier 2, they have 3 BULK and 20 HP , which would be impossible for a beacon.

    Like PC classes, NPC types fall into a few basic roles:

    • Artillery: Deals damage over long range.
    • Controller: Manipulates foes or the battlefield to gain an advantage.
    • Defender: Protects their allies or draws attention to themselves.
    • Striker: Deals damage over close-to-medium range.
    • Support: Assists allies, either by healing, mitigating damage, or enhancing other characters.

    The full list of NPC types can be found on p. 387.

    NPC TEMPLATES

    Templates are additional sets of features that can be added to NPCs, which can drastically alter how they play. There are two types of templates: thematic and mechanical .

    Thematic templates represent sets of abilities associated with specific types of enemies, like Beasts, Oozes, and Undead.

    Mechanical templates represent NPCs that are easier or harder than normal, like a group of weak Minions or a Mini-Boss. Mechanical templates impact how many points it costs from the NPC budget to add that NPC to the combat scene.

    NPCs can have multiple templates at once, although no more than two is a good guideline.

    NPC TIER

    NPCs come in one of three tiers: tier 1 ( T1 ), tier 2 ( T2 ), and tier 3 ( T3 ).

    NPCs of higher tiers are stronger and tougher than those of lower tiers. Each tier is meant to provide a challenge to characters of certain levels:

    • T1: Level 1-4
    • T2: Level 5-8
    • T3: Level 9-12

    It is possible for the beacons to face NPCs of a higher tier than their current level, but these fights represent harder challenges.

    An NPC's tier changes certain values. When an NPC's rules contain three values separated by a slash (e.g., +1/+2/+3 or 5/10/15), this indicates different values used by different tiers. T1 NPCs use the first value, T2 NPCs use the middle value, and T3 NPCs use the last value.

    NPC FEATURES

    NPC types and templates provide unique sets of features for NPCs, which are their traits, equipment, and techniques. These features come in three types: base features, extra features, and universal features . Base features and extra features come from an NPCs type and template, whereas universal features are available to all NPCs.

    NPCs always have their base features equipped by default. Extra features, on the other hand, are optional abilities. When choosing your NPCs, you can optionally give an NPC 0-2 extra features from their pool of available extra features.

    Universal features (p. 304) count as extra features, but are available to every NPC instead of being tied to a specific NPC type or template.

    Unlike PCs, NPCs don't have equipment slots or MEMORY . They just equip whatever abilities are provided by their chosen base and extra features, regardless of their listed equipment size.

    Because NPCs don't have GRIT , every ability that involves an attack has its own attack bonus. The description for each of these abilities lists the specific attack bonus to use, including whether there is any or .

    For example, a Cleaver NPC attacking with their ENERGY CLEAVER weapon would roll 1d20+2 at tier 1.

    Energy Cleaver FIGHT Energy Cleaver FIGHT
    MELEEWEAPON HEAVYMAGITECH PIERCING MELEEWEAPON HEAVYMAGITECH PIERCING
    +2/+4/+6 VS DODGE REACH 1 4/6/8 ASTRAL

    NPC INITIATIVE

    NPCs take their turns in a different way than PCs. Instead of acting based on the phase of the standard action they want to perform, each NPC has an INITIATIVE , which ranges from 1-8. This specifies the phase in which they take their turn. During that phase, the NPC can take any action, not only those options available to PCs during that phase.

    For example, Elementalist NPCs have INITIATIVE 1 . They take their turn during PHASE BOLSTER , at which time they can take any action. They can use the VOLLEY action to attack with their PRIMAL STAFF , a ranged weapon, during their turn even though it's not PHASE SKIRMISH , because they don't follow the same action rules as the PCs.

    Certain templates can give an NPC multiple turns, and therefore multiple INITIATIVES . For example, the Elite template gives an NPC 2 turns each round. It takes their normal INITIATIVE and adds 5 to determine their second INITIATIVE . For example, Vulture NPCs have

    INITIATIVE 3 . An Elite Vulture would have two INITIATIVES of 3 and 8 (3 + 5 = 8). Templates that provide additional turns explain when they happen.

    Some NPC actions are slightly different from PC actions. The next page explains the differences.

    RECHARGING

    Certain NPC abilities have a Recharge X+ tag.

    Whenever an NPC uses a Recharge ability, it can't be used again until that ability recharges.

    At the start of each of the NPC's turns after using a Recharge ability, the NPC rolls a d6 recharge die . If the result equals or exceeds the Recharge value (X) of any Recharge abilities they have, those abilities recharge.

    For example, a Firebug uses Siegebreaker , a Recharge 5+ ability. At the start of the Firebug's next turn, they roll a d6 and get a 6. Because this is greater than 5, the ability recharges, and the Firebug can use it again this turn.

    NPCs only make one recharge roll each turn, but that roll can recharge multiple abilities at once.

    NPC SPECIAL RULES

    There are some additional ways that NPCs differ from PCs:

    • NPCs start with WOUND CAP 1 and are defeated when they take a Wound. If an NPC has WOUND CAP 2+ , they follow the normal Wound rules for PCs.
    • NPCs start with OVERSTRESS CAP 1 but they don't make an overstress roll when they exceed their STRESS CAP . Instead, while exceeding their STRESS CAP , they are VULNERABLE . If an NPC has OVERSTRESS CAP 2+ , they follow the normal Overstress rules for PCs.
    • If an NPC doesn't have a STRESS CAP , they take Stress as Force damage.
    • NPCs can't use the Reroll Table .
    • NPCs can't SURGE .

    DESIGNING NPCS

    When designing an NPC, do the following:

    • 1 Pick an NPC type.
    • 2 Choose templates, if any.
    • 3 Choose 0-2 extra features. Extra features can be chosen from the NPC's type, the list of universal NPC features (p. 304), and any templates.
    • 4 Choose a tier.

    NPCs can look or act like anything. A Fortress NPC could be a literal walking tower, or even a giant spider.

    TINKERING WITH NPCS

    The abilities listed with each NPC type are examples meant to be evocative. Changing a weapon from one weapon type to another (e.g., making a blade a longarm) doesn't really affect anything.

    In general, you can change whether NPC features are weapons, support items, skills, or spells without

    NPC ACTIONS

    During their turns, NPCs can perform a standard action , a standard movement , and a minor action .

    Phase Bolster

    DEFEND: Attacks against this NPC receive +1 until the start of their next turn.

    REFRESH: This NPC regains all MP then can choose one of the following:

    • Reload all Reloading weapons and abilities.
    • Clear a condition.

    Phase Channel

    CHANNEL: As normal, but if the NPC takes this action during PHASE RELEASE (only possible for NPCs with multiple turns), they can't RELEASE it until the next round.

    Phase Skirmish

    VOLLEY: As normal, but improvised spell attacks have a +1/+2/+3 attack bonus.

    MARK:

    As normal.

    SEARCH:

    As normal.

    Phase Reposition

    RUSH: As normal.

    HIDE:

    As normal.

    altering gameplay too much. For example, changing the Gunner's REPEATER from a weapon to a spell isn't a big change.

    If you want to make an NPC more challenging, you can give them additional extra features beyond the normal 0-2.

    NPCs have access to some of the same actions as PCs, but with some changes. Their actions are outlined below.

    Phase Brawl

    FIGHT: As normal, but improvised weapon attacks have a +1/+2/+3 attack bonus.

    SHOVE: As normal, but with a +1/+2/+3 attack bonus.

    GRAPPLE: As normal, but with a +1/+2/+3 attack bonus.

    Phase Release

    RELEASE:

    As normal.

    Phase Full Attack

    FULL ATTACK: As normal, but NPCs need a special feature to be able to FULL ATTACK . If an NPC has multiple turns, they can FULL ATTACK 1/turn.

    Special Actions

    READY: As normal.

    Reactions

    OPPORTUNITY ATTACK:

    As normal.

    The Architect rigs the battlefield in their favor, laying down traps for their enemies to stumble upon.

    A R C H I T E C T

    TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER TIER TIER TIER TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3
    Size: 1/2 Save Target: 12 Size: 1/2 Save Target: 15 Size: 1/2 Save Target: 18
    Armor: 2 Initiative: 5 Armor: 2 Initiative: 5 Armor: 3 Initiative: 5
    Scope: 5 Scope: 5 Scope: 5
    ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY ABILITY ABILITY ABILITY ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES
    Bulk: -1 Mind: 2 Bulk: -1 Mind: 4 Bulk: -1 Mind: 6
    Agility: 1 Magic: 0 Agility: 2 Magic: 0 Agility: 3 Magic: 0
    ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES
    HP: 12 Stress Cap: 6 HP: 14 Stress Cap: 6 HP: 16 Stress Cap: 6
    Dodge: 10 A-Def: 7 Dodge: 11 A-Def: 8 Dodge: 12 A-Def: 9
    Speed: 5 MP: 4 Speed: 5 MP: 4 Speed: 5 MP: 4

    A rchitects are Trap -focused NPCs, placing their Traps in chokepoints and forcing their enemies to either avoid areas or disable them to proceed. There is no limit to the number of Traps an Architect can place, and if not dealt with, they can quickly fortify a position. The Architect and their allies don't trigger these Traps , and the Architect has a number of ways to knock enemies right into them.

    Beware of high-mobility beacons who can easily move around isolated Traps , or artillery beacons that can take out Architects before they have a chance to litter the battlefield with Traps .

    Base Features

    Hazards

    SUPPORT ITEM

    HEAVY

    TRAP

    The Architect deploys one of the following Traps to a free space within RANGE 3 . Each Trap creates a BURST 1 AOE when triggered.

    • Sticky Trap: When triggered, characters in the AOE must make a BULK save. Failure: They are IMMOBILIZED until cleared. Success: They are SLOWED until the end of their next turn.
    • Explosive Trap: When triggered, characters in the AOE must make an AGILITY save. Failure: They take 8/12/16 FORCE . Success: They take 4/6/8 FORCE .
    • Concussion Trap: When triggered, characters in the AOE must make a BULK save. Failure: They are DISARMED and SILENCED until the end of their next turn. Success: They are either DISARMED or SILENCED instead, their choice.
    • Pitfall Trap: When triggered, creates a zone of dangerous terrain ( AGILITY , 5 PHYSICAL ) that lasts until the end of the scene. Characters in the zone when it is created fall PRONE .

    The Architect and their allies don't trigger these Traps , but can be affected by them.

    If this support item would be destroyed, one of the Architect's Trap options is instead rendered unavailable.

    MINOR ACTION

    Extra Features

    Fast Deployment

    TRAIT

    The Architect can deploy two of their Traps at once.

    Lodestone Sling VOLLEY +1/2/3 VS DODGE RANGED WEAPON MAIN CLUB ARCING RANGE 8, BLAST 1 4/5/6 FORCE

    On Attack: The attack gains either Push 1 or Pull 1 .

    Natural Camouflage MINOR ACTION SUPPORT ITEM MAIN MANA 1 RANGE = SCOPE (5/5/5)

    The Architect camouflages a space within RANGE until the end of the scene. Characters fully within camouflaged spaces are INVISIBLE .

    The Architect teleports any number of their Traps within Range to new free spaces within Range.

    Sticky Bomb VOLLEY SUPPORT ITEM LIGHT MANA 1 RANGE 5

    One target within Range must make an AGILITY save. Failure: They have a sticky bomb attached to them. At the end of the target's next turn, the bomb explodes, creating a BURST 1 AOE. A character adjacent to the target can disarm the bomb with a successful AGILITY check as a minor action .

    All characters in the AOE must make an AGILITY save. The target with the sticky bomb is affected as if they failed the save. Failure: They take 8/10/12 FORCE . Success: They take 4/5/6 FORCE .

    Tripwire TRAIT RECHARGE 5+

    REACTION (1/ROUND)

    This ability does not require line of sight.

    Trigger: An enemy moves within RANGE 3 of one of the Architect's HIDDEN Hazards .

    Effect: The enemy must make a MIND save. Failure: The Hazard triggers as if it were in one of the triggering character's spaces (GM's choice).

    Cannonball SKILL

    PHASE

    C H A R G E R

    The Charger is a fast-moving, close-range attacker. They can quickly close the gap between them and their target, and are protected while doing so.

    TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3
    Size: 1 Save Target: 10 Size: 1 Save Target: 12 Size: 1 Save Target: 14
    Armor: 1 Initiative: 4 Armor: 1 Initiative: 4 Armor: 1 Initiative: 4
    Scope: 5 Scope: 5 Scope: 5
    ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES
    Bulk: 1 Mind: 0 Bulk: 2 Mind: 1 Bulk: 3 Mind: 1
    Agility: 1 Magic: 0 Agility: 2 Magic: 0 Agility: 4 Magic: 0
    ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES
    HP: 15 Stress Cap: 6 HP: 18 Stress Cap: 6 HP: 21 Stress Cap: 6
    Dodge: 10 A-Def: 7 Dodge: 12 A-Def: 7 Dodge: 14 A-Def: 7
    Speed: 7 MP: 2 Speed: 8 MP: 2 Speed: 9 MP: 2

    C hargers are fast-moving attackers that utilize hit-and-run tactics. They should always be moving, and they gain benefits when using RUSH . Their main weapons push foes on hits, which lets them pivot to new targets without provoking opportunity attacks. Preventing a Charger from moving shuts down many of their abilities and leaves them vulnerable.

    Base Features

    Lance

    FIGHT +1/2/3 VS DODGE

    MELEE WEAPON

    HEAVY LONGARM

    RELIABLE 2/3/4,

    PUSH 1

    REACH 1

    6/8/10 PHYSICAL

    Extra Features

    REPOSITION

    The Charger moves up to their SPEED (7/8/9) in a straight line. If they move at least 3 spaces and end their movement adjacent to an enemy, all enemies in a BURST 1 AOE centred on the Charger take 3 PHYSICAL and must make a BULK save. Failure: They fall PRONE and are DAZED until the end of their next turn.

    Lasso

    SUPPORT ITEM

    MAIN

    The Charger makes a melee weapon attack against an adjacent character.

    On Hit: The target takes 2 STRESS ; the Charger can immediately move up to their SPEED (7/8/9) ; and the target is dragged along, mirroring the Charger's movement. This counts as forced movement.

    FIGHT +1/2/3 VS DODGE

    Retaliation

    SKILL

    Characters that make an OPPORTUNITY ATTACK against the Charger become MARKED .

    Trample

    TRAIT

    When the Charger moves, they ignore ENGAGEMENT and can move through spaces occupied by enemies of their SIZE or smaller. They deal 2/3/4 PHYSICAL to enemies they move through, 1/turn per character.

    The Cleaver is a close-range brawler with hard-hitting, wide-swinging attacks.

    Tipped Explosive

    SUPPORT ITEM MAIN

    The Charger's LANCE has Push 3 instead of Push 1 . If a character pushed this way collides with another character or obstruction, they stop moving and take an additional 3/4/5 PHYSICAL .

    Wild Charge

    SKILL

    When the Charger uses CHARGE ATTACK , they can force the target to make a BULK save before making the attack. Failure: The target falls PRONE .

    C L E AV E R

    TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3

    ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES
    HP: 16 Stress Cap: 5 HP: 20 Stress Cap: 5 HP: 25 Stress Cap: 5
    Dodge: 8 A-Def: 6 Dodge: 9 A-Def: 6 Dodge: 10 A-Def: 6
    Speed: 4 MP: 1 Speed: 4 MP: 1 Speed: 4 MP: 1

    C leavers are physical brutes with dangerous attacks. They want to position themselves near as many foes as possible and attack as often as they can to make the most use of their WIDE ARC trait. It is difficult to defend against Cleavers, as they increase FOCUS costs or even outright destroy FOCUS . Fortunately for their enemies, Cleavers have low A-DEF and STRESS CAP scores, and lack any abilities that work at range aside from HOOK .

    Base Features

    VS DODGE

    Chopper

    HEAVY BLADE

    RELIABLE 2/3/4

    On Hit: The target loses 1 FOCUS .

    On Crit: The target loses 3 FOCUS .

    Break Guard

    SKILL

    Any effects triggered by or targeting the Cleaver that cost FOCUS cost an additional +1 FOCUS .

    Energy Cleaver FIGHT +2/4/6 VS DODGE MELEE WEAPON HEAVY MAGITECH PIERCING REACH 1 4/6/8 ASTRAL

    Full Attacker

    The Cleaver can FULL ATTACK .

    Wide Arc

    TRAIT

    TRAIT

    When the Cleaver makes a melee attack, all adjacent enemies take 1 PHYSICAL .

    Hook

    MINOR ACTION +1/2/3 VS DODGE

    HEAVY

    RANGE 5

    The Cleaver makes a ranged weapon attack against a character within RANGE .

    On Hit: The target is pulled to the closest free space adjacent to the Cleaver.

    Opportunist

    TRAIT

    The Cleaver can OPPORTUNITY ATTACK any number of times each round.

    Shatter Weapon

    SKILL RECHARGE 5+

    When the Cleaver hits with a weapon, the target must make a BULK save. Failure: They are DISARMED until the end of their next turn.

    Shred

    If the Cleaver hits the same target with two weapon attacks in the same turn, the target is SUNDERED until the end of their next turn.

    Whirlwind

    SKILL RECHARGE 5+

    BRAWL

    BURST 2

    All enemies in the AOE must make an AGILITY save. Failure: They take 5/6/7 PHYSICAL and lose 1 FOCUS . Success: They take 3/3/4 PHYSICAL .

    Additionally, until the start of the Cleaver's next turn, any attacks against the Cleaver while adjacent to them trigger WIDE ARC .

    Wind Up

    SKILL RECHARGE 6+

    An adjacent character must make a BULK save. Failure: They take 10/12/14 PHYSICAL , lose all FOCUS , and are SUNDERED until the end of their next turn. Success: They take 5/6/7 PHYSICAL and lose 1 FOCUS .

    PHASE

    BRAWL

    PHASE

    Conjurers summon allies to assist them in battle, overwhelming their foes with numbers if left to their own devices.

    C O N J U R E R

    TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3
    Size: 1 Save Target: 11 Size: 1 Save Target: 13 Size: 1 Save Target: 15
    Armor: 0 Initiative: 2 Armor: 0 Initiative: 2 Armor: 0 Initiative: 2
    Scope: 10 Scope: 12 Scope: 15
    ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES
    Bulk: -2 Mind: 2 Bulk: -2 Mind: 3 Bulk: -2 Mind: 4
    Agility: 0 Magic: 2 Agility: 0 Magic: 4 Agility: 0 Magic: 6
    ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES
    HP: 8 Stress Cap: 8 HP: 10 Stress Cap: 8 HP: 12 Stress Cap: 8
    Dodge: 10 A-Def: 12 Dodge: 10 A-Def: 15 Dodge: 10 A-Def: 18
    Speed: 5 MP: 3 Speed: 5 MP: 5 Speed: 5 MP: 7

    W hether they be demonologists, necromancers, or beastmasters, all conjurers are expert summoners. They specialize in calling on conscripts, versatile Summons that can be any sort of creature. Conjurers stay in the back and place their conscripts in front of them, letting their Summons whittle down enemies while the Conjurer channels powerful spells.

    Base Features

    VOLLEY

    Drag Down

    RANGE = SCOPE (10/12/15)

    Conjure Conscript

    SPELL

    MANA 1, SUMMON

    Conscript ( SIZE 1/2 , HP 5/8/10 , DODGE/A-DEF 10 , SPEED 0 )

    The Conjurer creates two conscripts within RANGE , up to a maximum of six conscripts at a time.

    During each of the Conjurer's turns, but not during the turn in which they were summoned, each conscript attacks the closest enemy with the Conscript Attack weapon.

    All conscripts are defeated when their Conjurer is defeated.

    Conscript Attack

    RANGED WEAPON

    VOLLEY +1/3/5 VS DODGE

    RANGE 8 4/5/6 PHYSICAL

    SPELL

    CHANNEL

    RANGE = SCOPE (10/12/15), BLAST 1

    On Release: Enemies in the AOE choose one of the following:

    • They take 2/3/4 STRESS and are VULNERABLE until the end of their next turn.
    • They take 6/8/10 FORCE and are DISARMED until the end of their next turn.

    Focus Fire

    TRAIT

    When the Conjurer causes an enemy to become MARKED , their conscripts will attack that enemy this round instead of the nearest enemy, if possible.

    Seize Command

    SPELL

    VOLLEY

    RANGE = SCOPE (10/12/15)

    The Conjurer targets an enemy Summon within RANGE . The creator of that Summon must make a MAGIC save. Failure: The Conjurer gains control of the Summon . Its allegiance is switched until the end of the Conjurer's next turn; it treats its former allies as enemies and its former enemies as allies.

    The original creator of the Summon can't dismiss or resummon it while it is commanded by the Conjurer.

    Bodyguard

    Extra Features

    TRAIT

    Each of the Conjurer's conscripts can INTERPOSE 1/ round without spending FOCUS .

    Improved Conscripts

    TRAIT

    When the Conjurer summons a conscript, they can give it one of the following improvements:

    • Mage: When the conscript attacks, enemies adjacent to the target take 2/3/4 FORCE .
    • Rogue: The conscript's attacks gain Reliable 2/3/4 .
    • Tank: The conscript gains +3 ARMOR .
    • Warrior: The conscript auto-hits when attacking adjacent enemies.

    Minor Action: The Conjurer gives an existing conscript within SCOPE (10/12/15) one of these improvements. Each conscript can only have one improvement at a time.

    Mana Tap

    RANGED SPELL ATTACK

    VOLLEY +2/3/4 VS A-DEF

    AETHERIC, INDIRECT

    RANGE = SCOPE (10/12/15)

    2/3/4 STRESS

    On Hit: The Conjurer regains 2 MP .

    Rupture SPELL

    CHANNEL

    On Release: All of the Conjurer's Summons (ignoring line of sight) create BURST 1 AOEs. Enemies in these AOEs must make an AGILITY save. Failure: They take 4/6/8 LUNAR + 3/4/5 DISCORD for each of these AOEs they are in. Success: They take 2/3/4 LUNAR + 1/2/3 DISCORD for each of these zones they are in.

    Soulless Investiture VOLLEY +1/3/5 VS A-DEF RANGED WEAPON LIGHT ARTIFACT AETHERIC RANGE 10 3/4/5 LUNAR

    The Conjurer can attack with this weapon from one of their Summons within SCOPE (10/12/15) , drawing line of sight and determining cover from one of the Summon's spaces.

    Transposition SPELL MANA 1

    PHASE

    REPOSITION

    RANGE = SCOPE (10/12/15)

    The Conjurer teleport any number of their conscripts within RANGE up to 4 spaces.

    CONJURER TEMPLATES

    Be careful when using the Conjurer with the Minion template. This combination can result in the very fast creation of lots of Summons , which can slow down the game.

    The Elementalist is a magical defender who calls upon the elements to protect their allies.

    E L E M E N TA L I S T

    TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3
    Size: 1 Save Target: 10 Size: 1 Save Target: 12 Size: 1 Save Target: 14
    Armor: 0 Initiative: 1 Armor: 0 Initiative: 1 Armor: 0 Initiative: 1
    Scope: 10 Scope: 10 Scope: 10
    ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES
    Bulk: 0 Mind: 1 Bulk: 0 Mind: 2 Bulk: 0 Mind: 3
    Agility: 0 Magic: 1 Agility: 1 Magic: 2 Agility: 1 Magic: 4
    ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES
    HP: 16 Stress Cap: 8 HP: 18 Stress Cap: 9 HP: 20 Stress Cap: 10
    Dodge: 8 A-Def: 8 Dodge: 8 A-Def: 9 Dodge: 8 A-Def: 10
    Speed: 5 MP: 6 Speed: 5 MP: 7 Speed: 5 MP: 9

    E lementalists protect their allies with magic, supporting them with arcane shields and preventing enemy access to certain areas. These units work from the back lines, lacking their own direct defenses, and are easily overwhelmed. Elementalists are also heavily dependent on MP , and negating their ability to regain it, or causing them to burn through it too quickly can cause them to waste actions.

    Base Features

    TRAIT

    Elemental Attunement

    Elemental Shield

    The Elementalist is attuned to one of the four elements: Air , Earth , Fire , or Water . They can attune to additional elements with the IMPROVED ATTUNEMENT extra feature. When the Elementalist chooses an elemental effect, they can only choose from elements to which they are attuned.

    Embankment

    SPELL

    ARCING, MANA 2

    RANGE = SCOPE (10/10/10), LINE 3

    This AOE is a zone that can face any direction. The zone can't be adjacent to other zones created by EMBANKMENT . It lasts until the end of the scene. The Elementalist chooses one of the following elemental effects from those to which they are attuned:

    • Air: The zone provides soft cover to characters inside it and ranged weapon attacks can't be made into or through the zone.
    • Earth: The zone becomes SIZE 3 hard cover . This cover is an obstruction.
    • Fire: Characters that start their turn within the zone or enter it for the first time during their turn take 3/4/5 ASTRAL + 2 DISCORD .
    • Water: The zone counts as difficult terrain . Characters that start their turn within the zone or enter it for the first time during their turn must make an AGILITY save. Failure: They fall PRONE .

    DEFEND

    SPELL

    MANA 2

    DEFEND

    RANGE = SCOPE (10/10/10)

    The Elementalist or an ally within RANGE gains 5/6/7 TEMP HP , and the Elementalist chooses one of the following elemental effects to which they are attuned:

    • Air: The target gains resistance to Force . When they are hit by an attack that removes all their TEMP HP , the attacker must make an AGILITY save. Failure: They fall PRONE .
    • Earth . The target gains resistance to Physical . When they are hit by an attack that removes all their TEMP HP , the attacker must make a BULK save. Failure: They are SUNDERED until the end of their next turn.
    • Fire . The target has resistance to Astral . When they are hit by an attack that removes all their TEMP HP , the attacker must make an AGILITY save. Failure: They take 4/5/6 DISCORD .
    • Water. The target has resistance to Lunar . When they are hit by an attack that removes all their TEMP HP , the attacker must make a MAGIC save. Failure: They are SLOWED until the end of their next turn.

    A character can only be affected by one elemental shield at a time, with new ones replacing the effects of the old one.

    Primal Staff VOLLEY +1/2/3 VS A-DEF RANGED WEAPON MAIN ARTIFACT AETHERIC RANGE 10 1/2/3 DISCORD

    Dual Shields

    Extra Features

    SKILL

    When the Elementalist uses ELEMENTAL SHIELD , they can spend 3 MP instead of the normal cost to target two characters at once.

    Elemental Mastery TRAIT

    Whenever the Elementalist would choose an elemental effect, they can instead choose two from those to which they are attuned.

    Elemental Sphere

    SPELL

    DEFEND

    MANA 1, SUMMON RANGE = SCOPE (10/10/10)

    Elemental Sphere ( SIZE 1/2 , HP 5/8/10 , DODGE/A-DEF 10 , SPEED 0 )

    The Elementalist calls forth an elemental sphere within RANGE . Characters the sphere moves through must make an AGILITY save. Failure: They are subjected to one of the following elemental effects, chosen at the time of summoning from those to which the Elementalist is attuned:

    • Air: The target slides 2 spaces .
    • Earth: The target is knocked PRONE .
    • Fire: The target takes 4/5/6 ASTRAL .
    • Water: The target is SLOWED until the end of their next turn.

    As a minor action , the Elementalist can move the sphere up to 4 spaces in a straight line, moving it through spaces occupied by other characters and ignoring ENGAGEMENT .

    Enchanted Staff SUPPORT ITEM LIGHT ENCHANTMENT

    This Enchantment applies to the Elementalist's PRIMAL STAFF . On a hit with this weapon, the Elementalist can spend 1 MP to apply one of the following effects:

    • Air: The target is pushed 2 spaces .
    • Earth: The target is SUNDERED until the end of their next turn.
    • Fire: Enemies adjacent to the target take 1 DISCORD .
    • Water: The target's SPEED is halved until the end of their next turn.

    Improved Attunement

    TRAIT

    The Elementalist is attuned to an additional element. This trait can be taken multiple times, choosing a new element each time.

    Improved Embankment TRAIT

    The Elementalist's EMBANKMENT spell becomes LINE 5 .

    These Expendables overwhelm their foes with sheer numbers.

    E X P E N D A B L E

    TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER TIER TIER TIER TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3
    Size: 1/2 Save Target: 10 Size: 1/2 Save Target: 12 Size: 1/2 Save Target: 14
    Armor: 0 Initiative: 5 Armor: 0 Initiative: 5 Armor: 0 Initiative: 5
    Scope: 5 Scope: 5 Scope: 5
    ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY ABILITY ABILITY ABILITY ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES
    Bulk: 2 Mind: -2 Bulk: 3 Mind: -2 Bulk: 4 Mind: -2
    Agility: -1 Magic: 0 Agility: 0 Magic: 0 Agility: 1 Magic: 1
    ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES
    HP: 5 Stress Cap: 5 HP: 7 Stress Cap: 5 HP: 9 Stress Cap: 5
    Dodge: 7 A-Def: 7 Dodge: 9 A-Def: 9 Dodge: 11 A-Def: 11
    Speed: 5 MP: 1 Speed: 5 MP: 1 Speed: 6 MP: 1

    E xpendables are cannon fodder, a step above Minions. Because they are deployed in pairs (see QUANTITY OVER QUALITY ), they try to use their superior numbers to defeat their foes. Expendables aren't expected to survive encounters, and try to either deal as much damage as they can or hinder their foes so their allies can take them out.

    Base Features

    Claws

    FIGHT +2/4/6 VS DODGE

    MELEE WEAPON

    MAIN CLUB REACH 1

    4/5/6 PHYSICAL

    On Hit: The target is GRAPPLED .

    Gnaw

    PHASE

    BRAWL

    SKILL

    Quantity Over Quality

    TRAIT

    The Expendable is two separate, identical NPCs, not one. Whenever you deploy an Expendable, you deploy two instead. Additionally, Expendables always count as BLOODIED and BREAKING .

    The Pack Descends

    The Expendable deals 5/6/7 PHYSICAL to a GRAPPLED character.

    TRAIT

    While adjacent to two or more Expendables, enemies are SUNDERED .

    Extra Features

    Basic Bow

    VOLLEY +1/2/3 VS DODGE

    RANGED WEAPON MAIN BOW ARCING

    RANGE 8

    4/5/6 PHYSICAL

    Clutch

    SKILL

    Characters GRAPPLED with the Expendable cannot make attacks that don't include the Expendable as a target. Characters that end their turn GRAPPLED by an Expendable take 2/3/4 PHYSICAL .

    Exploder

    TRAIT

    When the Expendable is defeated, they unleash a burst of energy. All characters in a BURST 1 AOE take 3/4/5 FORCE . The Expendable can choose to become defeated as a minor action . If they do so, the damage becomes 6/8/10 FORCE .

    Hunt by Scent

    TRAIT

    When the Expendable uses SEARCH , they automatically detect any HIDDEN or INVISIBLE creatures in SCOPE .

    Lash

    FIGHT +1/2/3 VS DODGE

    SUPPORT ITEM

    HEAVY

    RANGE 3

    The Expendable makes a melee weapon attack against a target within RANGE .

    On Hit: If the target is the same SIZE as the Expendable or smaller, they are pulled adjacent to and GRAPPLED by the Expendable. If the target is larger, the Expendable is pulled adjacent to them and they are then GRAPPLED by the Expendable.

    Scramble

    TRAIT

    EXPENDABLES AND TEMPLATES

    For the rest of the turn after using RUSH , the Expendable moves normally in difficult terrain and climbing costs half as much movement as normal.

    Expendables are particularly dangerous when paired with the Minion template. They are designed to be easily defeated and overwhelming in numbers. The Minion template intensifies both of these characteristics, with little additional downsides. Be careful if you decide to use this combination.

    F I R E B U G

    The Firebug is a frightening hard-hitter that overwhelms foes with searing damage.

    TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3
    Size: 2 Save Target: 10 Size: 2 Save Target: 12 Size: 2 Save Target: 15
    Armor: 2 Initiative: 5 Armor: 2 Initiative: 5 Armor: 3 Initiative: 5
    Scope: 5 Scope: 5 Scope: 10
    ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES
    Bulk: 1 Mind: 1 Bulk: 2 Mind: 2 Bulk: 4 Mind: 2
    Agility: -1 Magic: 1 Agility: -1 Magic: 2 Agility: -1 Magic: 3
    ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES
    HP: 14 Stress Cap: 8 HP: 16 Stress Cap: 8 HP: 18 Stress Cap: 8
    Dodge: 8 A-Def: 8 Dodge: 10 A-Def: 10 Dodge: 12 A-Def: 12
    Speed: 4 MP: 4 Speed: 4 MP: 5 Speed: 4 MP: 6

    W hile usually associated with fire, Firebugs can be portrayed as utilizing any type of energy. Focused on closerange AOE attacks, Firebugs wield devastating effects that deal damage over time - damage that can quickly grow out of control. Beacons that spread out weaken the effectiveness of Firebugs, so look for opportunities to keep them clustered together.

    Base Features

    Burnproof TRAIT Fuel Tank MINORACTION
    The Firebug chooses Astral or Lunar damage, with the following effects: SUPPORT ITEM HEAVY STRESSFUL 2
    TheFirebug has resistancetothechosendamage type and all Discord . The Firebug's effects that can deal either Astral Lunar deal the chosen damage type. The Firebug regains 1MP . Additionally, whenthis item is destroyed,theFirebugtakes 6/8/10PIERCINGFORCE . While this item is destroyed, the Firebug is considered
    or BLOODIED .

    Destructive Breath FIGHT +1/2/3 VS DODGE MELEE WEAPON HEAVY ARTIFACT MANA 1 REACH 1, CLOSE BLAST 2 4/5/6 DISCORD

    Uptick

    MINOR ACTION

    SKILL

    MANA 1, RECHARGE 5+ RANGE = SCOPE (5/5/10)

    The Firebug targets a character within RANGE that has any amount of Discord . That character's total Discord is doubled, but they don't take any additional discord damage from this increase.

    Contagious

    Trigger: An enemy within the Firebug's SCOPE fails a check to clear Discord .

    Effect: All enemies adjacent to the target take Astral or Lunar equal to the target's Discord .

    Distracting Burns

    TRAIT

    Whenever the Firebug deals a character Discord or increases a character's Discord , that character becomes MARKED .

    Growing Flames

    TRAIT

    When an enemy within RANGE 2 of the Firebug fails a check to clear Discord , their Discord increases by +2 before they take the damage.

    Extra Features

    SKILL REACTION (1/ROUND)

    Siegebreaker

    SKILL

    PHASE

    BRAWL

    ARCING, RECHARGE 5+

    RANGE 10, BLAST 2

    .

    All characters in the AOE must make an AGILITY save.

    Failure:

    They take

    2 DISCORD + 4/6/8 ASTRAL OR LUNAR

    Success:

    They take

    1 DISCORD + 2/3/4 ASTRAL OR LUNAR

    .

    Ring of Fire

    SKILL

    AURA 2

    Enemies that start their turn within this Aura take 2/3/4 DISCORD .

    While the Firebug is BLOODIED , this Aura is reduced to Aura 1 .

    Terrify SKILL RECHARGE 5+

    Brawl

    BURST 2

    All enemies within the AOE must make a MIND save. Failure: They take 4 STRESS and become MARKED and DAZED . They can attempt to clear DAZED with a MIND save as a minor action , clearing the condition on a success or taking an additional 1 STRESS on another failure.

    Success: They take 2 STRESS and become MARKED .

    F O R T R E S S

    The Fortress is a mobile castle, providing safety to those within it.

    TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 1 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 2 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3 TIER 3
    Size: 3 Save Target: 11 Size: 3 Save Target: 14 Size: 3 Save Target: 16
    Armor: 2 Initiative: 1 Armor: 2 Initiative: 1 Armor: 2 Initiative: 1
    Scope: 10 Scope: 10 Scope: 10
    ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES ABILITY SCORES
    Bulk: 3 Mind: 0 Bulk: 4 Mind: 0 Bulk: 6 Mind: 0
    Agility: -2 Magic: 0 Agility: -2 Magic: 1 Agility: -2 Magic: 2
    ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES ATTRIBUTES
    HP: 25 Stress Cap: 5 HP: 30 Stress Cap: 6 HP: 35 Stress Cap: 7
    Dodge: 6 A-Def: 6 Dodge: 7 A-Def: 7 Dodge: 8 A-Def: 8
    Speed: 4 MP: 2 Speed: 4 MP: 2 Speed: 4 MP: 3

    F ortresses are slow, bulky defenders that use their size to protect their allies. They provide a space in which their allies receive defensive bonuses. As such, Fortresses want to keep as many allies as possible within their spaces and stay the focus of enemy attacks. Allies within the Fortress have no protection from AOEs and are still susceptible to forced movement taking them outside the Fortress. Although they have a lot of HP , Fortresses are VULNERABLE to Piercing damage and easily become overstressed.

    PHASE

    Harness

    TRAIT

    Base Features

    Towering Wall SUPPORT ITEM HEAVY The Fortress's allies gain the benefits of cover from the Fortress as if they were a piece of hard cover . Additionally, as long as the Fortress's allies are fully within the Fortress's spaces, nonAetheric , non-AOE attacks against them target the Fortress instead.

    Heavy Frame

    VULNERABLE

    The Fortress is

    TRAIT

    to

    Piercing

    Discord cluding

    damage

    , in- immune

    . Additionally, the Fortress is to forced movement from smaller characters.

    Mounted Defenses

    RANGED WEAPON

    VOLLEY +2/3/4 VS DODGE

    HEAVY CLUB

    RANGE 15

    The Fortress's allies can share the Fortress's spaces, gaining hard cover from TOWERING WALL . Allies fully inside the Fortress move when the Fortress does, and are considered to be the same SIZE as the Fortress for the purposes of determining line of sight.

    ARCING

    4/5/6 PHYSICAL

    Allies fully within the Fortress's spaces can VOLLEY with this weapon.

    On Hit: The target is DAZED until the end of their next turn.

    Extra Features

    TRAIT

    Stomp

    SKILL

    MINOR ACTION

    All adjacent enemies must make a BULK save. Failure: They fall PRONE .

    Watchtower

    VOLLEY +1/2/3 VS A-DEF

    RANGED SPELL ATTACK

    AETHERIC, INDIRECT

    RANGE = SCOPE (10/10/10), BLAST 1

    2 STRESS

    On Hit: The target is SUNDERED until the end of their next turn.

    Barracks

    The Fortress counts as a reinforcement zone.

    Fortified

    TRAIT

    Allies fully within the Fortress's spaces gain ARMOR equal to the Fortress's ARMOR .

    Murder Holes

    SUPPORT ITEM

    HEAVY

    Allies fully within the Fortress's spaces gain +1 on ranged attack rolls.

    Siege Ram
